the debate is closed . </s>
the vote will take place on Thursday at 12.00 p. m. storms in Europe the next item is the Commission statement on the storms in Europe . </s>
Mr Barnier has the floor on behalf of the Commission . </s>
Mr President , ladies and gentlemen , you have just been speaking about the human , ecological and social consequences of yet another oil slick which has reached French shores . </s>
we are now speaking - and personally , I am very happy that we are - about the consequences of an historic storm , a veritable hurricane which affected France , and also the Federal Republic of Germany and Austria in the same period . </s>
when speaking about the consequences of such accidents or such terrible weather conditions , we are not only talking about the damage to the environment and to property , we are also talking - and this is a point I wish to make too - about the consequences of the storm , as well as of the oil slick , for men , women and families who , as Mrs de Palacio said a moment ago , are seriously traumatised , wounded , bruised , demoralised , the weakest of which are desperate . </s>
I have seen this myself . </s>
I really think that today we are seeing an expression of European solidarity , a solidarity demonstrated by words of moral support , but which is above all human . </s>
this is the solidarity that I would like to express on behalf of the whole Commission and , particularly , within the Commission , on behalf of my colleagues who have not forgotten their roots or their citizenship : Franz Fischler from Austria , Michaele Schreyer and Günther Verheugen from Germany , and Pascal Lamy and myself from France . </s>
this expression of feeling is to complement that already shown by the national authorities of these countries and by the tremendous surge of generosity and kindness that has been shown . </s>
and as we are talking about Europe , I would also like to take my hat off to the spontaneity and the willingness of the volunteers from the public electricity and telephone services , to the firemen and the road-workers who came spontaneously from all over Europe to help to re-open roads and to restore electricity and telephones . </s>
in some parts of France , some families have only had their telephones and electricity working again since yesterday or the day before . </s>
at the request of President Prodi , the Commission has held its first talks on this whole issue , a discussion during its first meeting of the year and now , as the President asked us to , I would like to tell you the results of our work to provide every response that the Union can muster in terms of rebuilding those parts of our economic , social and cultural heritage that were affected . </s>
this must be done within the limits of the regulations and the budget , having expressed our human and moral solidarity . </s>
ladies and gentlemen , the Commission will therefore make use of every instrument it has in order to help the affected Member States in this reconstruction and to provide any possible aid to the people and businesses affected . </s>
this will be done in order to complement and to top up the support and aid which have already been decided on by the national and regional authorities . </s>
as you know , the Commission has several instruments and tools which can provide aid for this rehabilitation and reconstruction effort and we intend to use all of these instruments , with the same desire to help , which Mrs de Palacio expressed when she spoke of the lessons to be learned from the Erika disaster . </s>
as far as the structural policy is concerned , I am personally going to look into how we can use the current decisions on the new generation of strategies for economic development which will be implemented over the next seven years . </s>
I will also look into how the appropriations , which have already been allocated , particularly to regions of rural , industrial and urban conversion and to fishing areas , that is , all the regions covered by objective 2 , can help this reconstruction . </s>
the objective 2 zoning was stopped by the Commission after consulting the various governments . </s>
in Germany 's case , the Commission 's decision was taken in December and today , the Commission has stopped the objective 2 zoning plan , not only for Luxembourg and Sweden , but also for France and Austria . </s>
in France 's case , where the damage is objectively the most extensive , the total available appropriations for the new objective 2 are EUR 5.4 billion for the period 2000-2006 . </s>
a preliminary study by the Commission services shows that on the basis of a financial allocation set up in proportion to the eligible population , 70 % of people affected by the storm may benefit from aid eligible under objective 2 . </s>
the 69 devastated French departments could thus receive around EUR 4.1 billion over the next seven years . </s>
for Germany and Austria , the corresponding total sums are respectively EUR 3 billion for Germany and EUR 600 million for Austria . </s>
I would also like to point out that the devastated areas which do not feature on this new zoning plan - and unfortunately there are some - which are not covered by objective 2 , but which were eligible under the previous objective 2 and objective 5b zoning , could also have access to appropriations available in the new programming period as provisional support . </s>
I would therefore like to suggest the most straightforward way in which structural appropriations could broadly contribute to the economic rehabilitation of devastated areas . </s>
of course , it is not a question of providing emergency aid since , as you know very well , two years ago the meagre appropriations available in the European budget under emergency aid were discontinued . </s>
it is a question of repair and lasting restoration in the context of the programmes currently in preparation and this , in my view , is our most important task . </s>
powers for programming actions and selecting priorities have , as you know , been devolved to each State . </s>
each government will therefore , under the conditions that I have just stated , have to establish its priorities and make choices . </s>
they will probably have new priorities , in order to take into account the consequences of this storm or of the oil slick . </s>
it is up to the governments of the countries concerned to distribute Community financial support among the various regions eligible for Structural funds , and therefore to propose to the Commission plans for action to be carried out at grass roots level . </s>
in order to be more specific though , by way of an example , I would like to remind you that all of these programmes in devastated areas will be able to finance the restoration of our historical and cultural heritage , areas of economic activity , and industrial or trading areas . </s>
they could also finance the channels necessary for the flow of raw materials and industrial products , for port infrastructures - both commercial and leisure ports , the infrastructure of airports involved in business travel or tourism , productive industrial investments , aid to businesses , and historical and cultural heritage for tourism as well as training for employees qualified under the European social Fund . </s>
the Commission is therefore entirely at the disposal of each of the Member States , in order to adapt , to rearrange this programming to the best effect . </s>
I would like to stress that this also applies to those who suffered the effects of the other storms at the beginning of December in Denmark , the United Kingdom and in Sweden . </s>
I know that Parliament adopted a previous resolution to this effect , on 16 December last year . </s>
I hope you do not mind if I stress , even though I have already said it twice , that this applies to Greece too , with regard to the consequences of the earthquake which occurred at the beginning of September , in accordance with objective 1 of the cohesion Fund . </s>
ladies and gentlemen , my colleague , Franz Fischler , adopts the same approach with regard to rural development . </s>
following the reform of the common agricultural policy which your Parliament approved last year , measures for rural development can , for the first time , be cofinanced throughout the Union 's rural areas by the ' guarantee ' section of the EAGGF . </s>
France will therefore benefit by EUR 760 million per year , Germany by EUR 700 million and Austria by EUR 423 million . </s>
this aid is available for devastated regions and is not constrained by the zoning which I am bound to apply under objective 2 . </s>
of the measures eligible under the EAGGF guarantee section , I would like to mention restoring agricultural and forestry production potential which has been damaged , reforestation , infrastructures for country roads and infrastructures for prevention and protection such as dykes and warning systems . </s>
in this context , probably the most special case is that of the timber industry , which has been affected particularly badly by these storms and to which we will be devoting all our attention , in both economic and environmental terms . </s>
I would like to say that the EAGGF could also allocate a Community cofinancing grant for the storage of wood . </s>
furthermore , in the fisheries sector , it is also possible to employ the structural instruments for cofinancing grants . </s>
France would thus have access to EUR 225 million for the period 2000-2006 . </s>
Community aid will thus be able to contribute to compensating fishermen and boat-owners for the temporary cessation of their activities in case of unforeseen events , up to a maximum of two months per year . </s>
it is also conceivable that the financial instrument for fisheries guidance , FIFG , will be able to provide assistance which could be used for standard investment projects . </s>
I am thinking here of fish-farming equipment , community facilities , restructuring , developing fish-farming sites , equipping fishing harbours , modernising boats , and I have already discussed these matters with Franz Fischler . </s>
finally , following consultation of course with my colleague , Mario Monti , the Commission would like to underline the fact that State aid earmarked for making good the damage caused by natural disasters or other extraordinary events can be considered compatible with the common market . </s>
it would therefore , in these circumstances , be authorised by the Commission . </s>
we can , then , embark on various courses of action straight away , for example in the area of energy , within the framework of the trans-European energy networks . </s>
I know that where the transmission of energy is concerned , there are many technical problems , particularly in the transmission of very high voltage energy . </s>
nevertheless , looking back to my quite recent time as Minister for the environment in France , when I campaigned for underground lines , I would like to point out , as one of you did a while ago , that in this area as in many others , prevention is much cheaper than a cure . </s>
I therefore hope that the Member States will vote in favour of laying telegraph , telephone and electricity networks underground , when this is technically possible , and that they are encouraged to do so . </s>
and that , ladies and gentlemen , covers the Community instruments , which offer many opportunities for very practical intervention . </s>
the European Union does not and will not do everything . </s>
it can nevertheless do a great deal , on condition that we are able to make use of these instruments , that you keep us informed and that Member States are able , in the days following these storms , to set out their priorities and to make choices . </s>
it is therefore very important that this House , as well as the Commission , passes this information and this practical expression of solidarity on to all partners involved and to the people concerned and affected . </s>
as far as I am concerned , I shall endeavour to do that myself this week , when I visit , the day after tomorrow , two French departments which have been particularly badly affected by the storms : Charente-Maritime , affected both by the hurricane and the oil slick , and Creuse . </s>
I shall also present today 's decision on objective 2 . </s>
tomorrow , 19 January , my colleague Michaele Schreyer will visit one of Germany 's most devastated regions , the black forest , in the state of Baden-Württemberg . </s>
with thanks for your patience , I should like to conclude this presentation , Mr President , by mentioning a subject close to my heart . </s>
this is one of the lessons we should learn from these disasters , which do not always have natural causes , but which often do . </s>
we are convinced that such disasters reinforce the need for better coordination within the Union of each State 's resources for repairs , emergency aid and civil protection . </s>
the Commission already has a unit for the coordination of civil protection , for which my colleague , Margot Wallström , is responsible . </s>
this unit , I might add , worked well when it had to deal with the oil slick , to find boats , arrange protection for beaches , machines for cleaning oil-covered birds to the extent that it is possible . </s>
the resources of 11 European countries were employed here , a fact which is sometimes forgotten , and which justifies the tribute I wanted to pay to the spontaneous solidarity shown by all European countries . </s>
nevertheless , I think that we must go even further . </s>
President Prodi , Margot Wallström and I are convinced that we need to find a more systematic way of developing a European intervention strategy , which is based on existing mechanisms in each country , on specialised units , such as fire brigades , vaccination and civil protection teams , mountain rescue dog teams and many more . </s>
Members of these units , whilst staying in their own countries , would undergo a common course of training . </s>
if needed , they could be mobilised , both within the European Union , as we have seen with this storm and the earthquake in Greece , and outside the Union , as happened in the cases of Turkey and South and Central America , following the tragic events that have taken place there . </s>
this really is an opportunity to create a genuine European civil protection force . </s>
today , we have a long way to go , even if the Helsinki European Council did take a step forward in this direction and Margot Wallström 's services are working on extending the role of the ' search and rescue task force ' . </s>
for the moment , of course , the Commission has neither the manpower nor the financial resources to take responsibility for such a task . </s>
we think , though , that with Margot Wallström and under the authority of President Romano Prodi , this is one of the lessons that we will be learning from this series of disasters , natural or otherwise , which have had such tragic consequences . </s>
in terms of efficiency and also of political clarity , this task force would be a symbol of our idea of the European Union . </s>
as far as I am concerned , I intend , within the Commission , to promote this idea as one of the lessons to be learned from this disaster . </s>
Mr President , the last days of 1999 were swept away by an incredibly violent storm , which struck France in the main , but also affected Germany , Spain , great Britain and Switzerland . </s>
I am sad to say that it accounted for more than 100 deaths , 88 of which occurred in France . </s>
the human cost has been enormous , but so has the material damage , and both public amenities and private property have been destroyed or seriously damaged . </s>
millions of homes are without electricity , telephones or running water . </s>
economic activities have been brought to a halt . </s>
in France alone , insurance companies are already estimating the costs of the damages at a total of FF 35-40 billion , which is between EUR 5 and 6 billion . </s>
this unprecedented natural disaster has called all available forces to action and has given rise to demonstrations of solidarity both within the Community 's borders and beyond . </s>
this is why I would like to thank all of those who gave a hand to the emergency services , and to the authorities and public services which were overwhelmed by the magnitude of the task . </s>
thank you , everyone , from the bottom of my heart , for this invaluable help . </s>
now that the shock has passed and the authorities ' vital functions have been re-established , I wonder , and I ask the Commission and the Council to consider as well the opportunity once again to incorporate a budget line for emergency aid into the Community budget , in order to address this kind of occurrence . </s>
the risks of weather-related disasters must not be ignored and , in the light of the consequences of such disasters and the speed of intervention that they require , I think that the Community would do well to have these resources again . </s>
it should be possible to release the emergency aid that we once had from the strict rules applied to the Structural funds . </s>
I also agree with Commissioner Barnier 's proposal to gradually set in place a European civil protection force - a proposal he put forward several months ago now - which we discussed , Commissioner , at the time of the earthquakes . </s>
it is obvious that the answer to the question I am asking about re-establishing Community emergency aid must be " yes " . </s>
next , I would like to address the huge problems encountered by one industry that has been particularly badly affected by this storm . </s>
I am talking about the forestry sector , whose business has been seriously damaged by the havoc that the terrible weather wrought on the forests . </s>
it must be understood that forests are not just landscape or environmental features . </s>
they also represent a major socio-economic sector in some regions , and this should not be overlooked . </s>
in France , more than 120 million cubic metres of wood were brought down by the wind . </s>
this represents around three years ' full harvest for producers . </s>
the consequences of this have been immediate . </s>
some foresters have lost everything . </s>
entire areas of forest have been devastated , which will , in a few weeks , cause security and fire-fighting problems . </s>
prices have already fallen because of the huge availability of timber , which has led to market saturation . </s>
infrastructures will suffer as a result of the abnormal volume of heavy goods vehicles , logging and handling gear on the roads . </s>
in these circumstances , it is crucial that we re-establish access routes , restore the land , and implement technical solutions , which will enable us to refit storage areas , and prop up timber prices . </s>
in the long term we will have to reforest , with all the resources we can muster . </s>
this is a whole raft of measures which should be adopted , Mr President , and I am delighted at the indications which the Commissioner gave , even though he knows that not everything is eligible under objective 2 . </s>
médoc is not , Commissioner , and I hope that , given the circumstances , the EAGGF will be able to replace objective 2 . </s>
Mr President , Commissioner , Parliament must not consider the unusually violent storms which have raged across various European regions to be a normal occurrence . </s>
it is certainly a tragic one , but it must be seen as something exceptional . </s>
on the contrary , these storms and their consequences are political events of major importance . </s>
how so ? </s>
why is this not an exceptional matter ? </s>
firstly because we now know that the occurrence of this kind of climatic phenomenon is never entirely unpredictable . </s>
we now know that this kind of storm is often related to phenomena of climate change and to greenhouse effect phenomena , with regard to which our citizens are waiting for the European Union to develop a comprehensive strategy of studies and forecasts . </s>
beyond that , though , what is at stake here , and this is why I say that it is , for us , an exceptionally important political phenomenon , is Europe 's ability to be what it claims to be , that is a Europe which is close to its citizens . </s>
this means , of course , that today we must send out a powerful message of solidarity to everyone affected by the storm and to the families that have lost a loved one . </s>
I would like to reiterate that we deplore the death of at least 90 people during this storm . </s>
this message must go to the craftsmen who have lost their work tools , to the farmers who have seen years of hard work disappear in a few minutes , and to everyone who saw in the 21st century in the cold and by candlelight . </s>
with regard to this , I am delighted at the work that has been done in recent days in this House between the various political groups in order to reach a joint resolution which , I hope , will be adopted tomorrow . </s>
but in specific terms , and going beyond fine words , this solidarity must obviously be translated into a major mobilisation of finances which will enable us to set about rebuilding the devastated economic sectors , the destroyed communications networks and , quite simply , to provide people with decent living conditions once again . </s>
I understand that some of the devastated areas were eligible under the Community Structural funds and that everything possible will be done to mobilise them as quickly as possible . </s>
I would like to say , though , that this is not sufficient . </s>
it is not sufficient because the reallocation of these ongoing appropriations , simply towards making good the damage , penalises long-term projects for investment and development already in place . </s>
above all , I think that public opinion will see this solution as unacceptable in terms of our political responsibility to Europe . </s>
our fellow citizens do not understand why the European Union is able to release considerable sums of aid in exceptional emergency conditions to help third countries which have suffered natural disasters , even if this aid is quite legitimate . </s>
from now on , if we want to ensure that Europe is not perceived by our citizens to be a machine churning out complex and pernickety regulations , this is something we must change . </s>
we have to come up with a new budgetary mechanism which will enable us , eventually , to raise sufficient funds in the event of an emergency and in the light of the great logistical and human mobilisation which we saw , with specialists coming from all over Europe . </s>
we must effectively facilitate the creation of a Europe-wide civil protection body . </s>
it is only when times are hard that we recognise our fellow human beings and appreciate their solidarity , and I think that this is the price of building a citizens ' Europe . </s>
Commissioner , I would like to thank you for the ideas you have put forward , particularly on the very specific proposals concerning the people affected and who are expecting a lot from the European Union , in terms of the help that we can offer them . </s>
in the days immediately following this terrible storm I wrote to you myself with a request for you to ask the French authorities to redraw the boundaries of objective 2 so that all areas devastated by the storms in France and elsewhere could benefit from objective 2 . </s>
I think that you must have done so , because you have not mentioned it . </s>
in fact , we all know that anyone who does not live within the perimeter of an objective 2 region will find it all but impossible to obtain aid . </s>
we should therefore put this situation right immediately . </s>
you also know that this will not only be a short-term problem , but also a medium and long-term one . </s>
let me explain . </s>
I was in the region of Lorraine at the time of this terrible storm which destroyed around 20 % of deciduous forest . </s>
indeed , for some ' forestry ' districts , which have lost 20 % of their trees , this represents a huge loss . </s>
we know , for example , that it takes between 150 and 200 years for a tree to reach maturity , so the loss these towns will suffer will not be spread over one , two or five years , but over many more . </s>
the towns concerned estimate that it will be spread over 40 years . </s>
I think that consequently it will be extremely difficult indeed to compensate these rural towns through subsidies for losses in their financial revenues . </s>
I think that this is something which we should continually bear in mind so that we do not lose sight of it in our various policies . </s>
it is true that the problem of the forestry sector is an extremely complex one . </s>
indeed , you spoke of releasing funds for timber storage on the grounds that its price must not depreciate . </s>
on the other hand , districts which have not been affected by the storms will also suffer , as the national forestry office has decided to freeze cuts in forestation for four years . </s>
those districts which have not suffered losses will therefore see their incomes decrease in any case . </s>
I am telling you all of this to illustrate how complex the problem is , and I thank the Commission once again for extending their analysis of this situation as far as it could . </s>
I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that , although there has indeed been an economic disaster , the real ecological catastrophes are still to come . </s>
as you yourself said , Commissioner , these disasters or storms do not always have natural causes , and we think that these are the first signs of climate change . </s>
we should therefore review our policies in order to take account of this fact . </s>
Mr President , Commissioner , France is still in shock as a result of this terrible disaster which has caused the death of dozens of people . </s>
no sector has been spared : road , air , rail , ports , electricity and telephone infrastructures , homes , school buildings and historic monuments , not forgetting of course agriculture and forestry , which have been devastated in many regions . </s>
people may have been traumatised in the areas where the damage has been greatest , but nobody has given up in the face of these terrible circumstances . </s>
in the days immediately following the storms , a fantastic spirit of solidarity and generosity developed , and still exists . </s>
elected representatives , municipal employees , citizens of France and of all Europe have rallied round to offer their help . </s>
I would like to pay special tribute to the commitment and the devotion of the public service employees who gave freely of their own time with the sole aim of helping those affected , to re-establish normality with regard to electricity , transport , telephones and the utilities . </s>
at this testing time , demonstrating their efficiency , the public services have reminded everybody how essential they are to the life of our society . </s>
I think that this should give us pause , particularly with a view to halting the current process of deregulation and privatisation . </s>
it is , of course , also crucial to tend to wounds , to make preparations for reconstruction and repair , while learning all the lessons that this terrible disaster has to teach us . </s>
I clearly heard what Commissioner Barnier was saying and indeed I appreciate his proposals , but personally , I would not set emergency goals and long-term goals in opposition to one another . </s>
on the contrary , I think that the situation shows in hindsight the relevance of the proposal my group made to restore a specific budget line for natural disasters in the Union . </s>
it would also be appropriate , of course , to increase the Structural funds for reconstruction in regions which have been devastated , particularly appropriations for rural development , for agro-food measures and for forestry . </s>
I took particular note of the proposals concerning objective 2 . </s>
finally , the idea that this type of disaster is connected to climate change due to the consequences of human activity upon the environment has been advanced . </s>
if this idea were to be confirmed , the European Union would have to make considerably more effort to ensure that the commitments given at the Kyoto Conference are respected . </s>
it should also make protection of the planet a priority , rather than the unbridled pursuit of profit . </s>
Mr President , everyone who has travelled here by car , train or aeroplane , has been able to see the extent of the damage , particularly in France , caused by hurricanes of a completely unprecedented violence which struck Europe at the end of last month . </s>
what can the Members of the European Parliament do when faced with such a widespread disaster ? </s>
firstly , I would like to pay tribute to the mayors and local representatives who , on a daily basis , have had to reassure their constituents , organise volunteers and cooperate with the public services . </s>
they have earned the confidence of their fellow-citizens . </s>
next , I would like to thank the emergency services and the armed forces of the Union 's Member States who , in a fine example of intergovernmental cooperation , came to support the efforts of their French colleagues . </s>
I would also like to consider the paradoxical situation we have with regard to emergency aid . </s>
if this disaster had taken place in Guatemala or Turkey , we could have immediately used the Community budget to help the victims , but in our own countries nothing of the kind is possible because there is no suitable budget line with which to do so . </s>
we must also ask the Commission not to prevent local authorities and individual States from coming to the assistance of businesses affected by the disaster by applying Community competition rules too strictly . </s>
I am thinking in particular here of fish and shellfish companies , which have been particularly badly hit . </s>
as you said , Commissioner , we must ensure that there is compensation for the forced cessation in activity and that appeals can be made to FIFG for investments that have been totally wiped out . </s>
beyond this , I think that implementing MAGPs in a mechanical way will no longer be appropriate in the coastal regions that have been affected . </s>
I therefore ask the Commission to stop doing so and , on the contrary , to help those who make their living from the sea to proceed to new investments , which they urgently need . </s>
Mr President , the storms which devastated France during the night between 26 and 27 December have caused , as has been said , 90 deaths and damage to a value of FF 75 billion , i. e. EUR 11 billion . </s>
almost three weeks after the disaster , several thousand people were still without electricity and telephones , 500 000 hectares of forestry land , or 100 million cubic metres of forest , have been ruined , and our historical heritage has also been affected , as the sad example of the park at the Palace of Versailles demonstrates . </s>
it seems quite natural that given such a disaster , national and European solidarity should go to the help of the devastated regions and those people who have been worst affected . </s>

this paradox , pointed out by the previous speaker , is that it is easier , a great deal easier , to offer help to victims of natural disasters outside the Union than within it . </s>

that , however , is another problem altogether . </s>
Mr President , Commissioner , Europe has undergone a tough ordeal at the start of this millennium . </s>
I would first like to express my heartfelt condolences to the families in mourning as a result of the appalling weather conditions that devastated Europe in December . </s>

it is Europe 's duty to support them and thereby complement the efforts of the governments of Member States affected by the disaster . </s>
I welcome Mr Barnier 's statement and I also welcome the measures which the Commission has announced . </s>

the Community action programme for civil protection , established by a Council decision on 9 December , was launched on 1 January 2000 . </s>
I ask Member States to grasp this opportunity . </s>
this programme must work at full capacity . </s>
although it may have been effective in certain areas - and I do not doubt the sincerity of Commissioner Barnier 's words - unfortunately it is still in its infancy when it comes to forestry . </s>
our priority , as we wait for Community-level funds to be freed up , is for material aid in terms of partnership exchanges between Member States . </s>
it is therefore a matter of urgency to improve forest roads , and to repair them as quickly as possible . </s>
lending forestry equipment and making personnel qualified in forestry management available are also covered by this measure . </s>
our next challenge will be to prevent the occurrence of phytosanitary problems which could result from having to abandon large amounts of wood in the forest , and from the pollution of ground water through having to store such large quantities of wood . </s>
finally , it is essential that we slow down the logging of standing wood , in order to give priority to the purchase of windfalls . </s>
these timber sales should be supported by strong media coverage in Member States . </s>
this aid for gathering timber is , of course , only the first stage of an aid package , which will take the form of aid for reforestation and aid for the development of rural areas . </s>
I ask the Commission to incorporate this into a study of how the situation should be managed now that the emergency is over . </s>
this is a very sad opportunity for Europe to renew its forestry heritage in line with the role that this plays in wildlife and nature conservation and in our economies . </s>
it is therefore a time for solidarity and cooperation between Member States in the face of an ecological and economic calamity . </s>
if this solidarity is to have been worthwhile , it is up to Europe to propose priority actions for safeguarding the timber industry . </s>
Hurricane " Lothar " should prompt us not to abide solely by the principle of undertaking repairs once the damage is done - something which is discussed at a very superficial level here - , but to switch to the precautionary principle , under the terms of which potential perpetrators are brought to book too . </s>
current programmes must be accelerated . </s>
for example , as they stand , the Commission 's programmes will preclude us from meeting our obligations under Kyoto . </s>
the trade in emissions rights is immoral to my mind and rather than solving the problem , it shelves it . </s>
the entire taxation system must be given an environmental perspective in the medium term . </s>
we must work more rapidly towards achieving the targets stipulated in the White Paper for renewable energy sources , as this would bring about a massive reduction in greenhouse gases . </s>
the new Commission has not put forward nearly enough on this subject , and what it has put forward is woefully inadequate ! </s>
Commissioner , Mr President , Lothar was a quite ordinary name hitherto . </s>
however , it has now achieved notoriety . </s>
the hurricane of the same name swept across Europe claiming numerous victims , mainly in France and Germany , but also in Switzerland , leaving a trail of destruction in its wake . </s>
the wind triumphed over electricity pylons , roofs , traffic signs and , ultimately over the forest . </s>
we have heard that in a short space of time the storm left us with approximately 120 million cubic metres of solid timber , and this is only an estimate . </s>
I have listened to you very attentively Commissioner , and welcome with open arms the fact that you are intending to go and see for yourself the effects the catastrophe has had in France and in Germany . </s>
if Mrs Schreyer is to visit the black forest sometime in the next few days , then any one farmer might ask her how the Commission and Europe would be able to help him as an individual . </s>

? </s>

the thinning-out we need is not being attended to ; the forests are not being tended to the requisite degree . </s>
what we need the Commission to do as a matter of urgency is to approve national aid , so as to avoid the competition issue being raised again at a later date . </s>
Mr President , Commissioner , permit me , first of all , to make reference to two facts . </s>
firstly , at the beginning of 1999 , NATO , with the participation of most Member States of the European Union , flattened Kosovo with bombs in the name of freedom . </s>
we are now endeavouring , at huge cost , to get the country back on its feet again and help its people , and rightly so . </s>

the Commission in Brussels responded to the victims ' cries for help with a shrugging of shoulders . </s>
" we do not have the wherewithal for that , " they said . </s>
this is wrong ! </s>
and no one can comprehend this attitude . </s>
certainly those who fear for their livelihood are at a complete loss . </s>
the citizens of the European Union expect solidarity , also from within this Community . </s>
I say they have a right to solidarity . </s>
indeed the European Parliament must make it its business to uphold this right in hours of need . </s>

it knows the ins and outs of aid provision better than any local organisation or authority . </s>
I call upon you , ladies and gentlemen , to support me in bringing home to the Commission the fact that what most Brussels offices are lacking is not so much the wherewithal for providing aid as the good will . </s>
permit me one further comment . </s>
although it was less evident in the case of the consequences of the storm , the tanker disaster off the French coast has made it very clear that we need to give the Commission a helping hand on another matter . </s>
the European Union needs rules governing environmental liability as a matter of urgency . </s>
we can no longer tolerate a situation where the general public has to foot the bill for damage that has often been caused by individuals involved in criminal machinations . </s>
we must make the perpetrators liable for all manner of damage done to our environment . </s>
then , for example , people will think twice before transporting oil in a tanker that is about to fall apart . </s>
when , in 1994 , over five years ago that is , I joined the legal Affairs Committee in this Parliament , I became rapporteur for the environmental liability dossier . </s>
to this day I am still awaiting an initiative from the Commission , which will actually enable me to start work . </s>
it is a scandalous state of affairs that must be ended with all haste , and I hope that February does not see this dossier being postponed yet again ! </s>
Mr President , Commissioner , the storms that took place at the turn of the millennium should galvanise us into thinking about certain problems . </s>
it has become clear that mankind continues to be unable to avoid natural disasters . </s>
there have always been natural disasters and there always will be . </s>
of course , there is a need for solidarity here . </s>
there is certainly a need for European civil protection , and the EU budget must also provide for a budget line covering natural disasters . </s>
but , most importantly , it is only ever man that makes the mistakes as far as the nature-mankind relationship is concerned - despite the fact that the same mistakes have often been made down through the centuries - and never nature , for nature cannot make mistakes . </s>
the extent of the damage caused on this occasion was determined by the population density , the type of infrastructure , and , of course , the many monocultures , if we are talking forests . </s>
of course , I am in favour of providing assistance where we can . </s>
but when it comes to aid , we ought to bear in mind that perhaps in future , more emphasis should be placed on laying electricity and telephone cabling underground . </s>
we must take account of smaller cycles and plant stable mixed woodland when undertaking reforestation , rather than monocultures . </s>
the most important subject for discussion in this context is the climate . </s>
to this day , we in Europe remain in the privileged position of having the Gulf stream , and the Gulf stream still does its stuff . </s>
America and south-east Asia are having a much worse time of it as far as climate and storms go . </s>
we are fortunate in having the Gulf stream . </s>
but in common with others , we too are having to endure the greenhouse effect . </s>
this is partly the work of human hand , as difficult as it is to demonstrate climate change using calculations . </s>
we must take more account of the guidelines produced at the Kyoto environmental conference . </s>
we must reduce CO2 emissions , employ renewable energies , and generally make enquiries , in this connection , as to how the forests of Europe are faring . </s>
Mr President , I think we should firstly express our sorrow for the victims . </s>
this is an irreparable loss . </s>
secondly , we welcome the solidarity between the French departments and citizens , and the solidarity of other countries with France , which is the country worst affected . </s>
as I have little time , Mr President , I would like to touch upon two elements of our resolution . </s>
I believe that the first one was implicitly recognised by the Commissioner in his speech when he wondered whether these catastrophes are natural or not . </s>
that is to say that experts are ever more convinced that climate change and human activities , in general terms , are linked to the increase seen in natural disasters in recent years . </s>
in fact , over the last decade , the temperature has risen more than in the rest of the century . </s>
therefore Europe must be clearly committed to the Kyoto Protocol and make specific proposals . </s>
secondly , I was rapporteur for civil protection in Europe and I completely agree with the Commissioner 's proposal to create a European civil protection body . </s>
furthermore , we should utilise an extraordinary budget line , since this is an extraordinarily catastrophic situation . </s>
first of all , we would like to express sympathy with all the families and communities that lost members in this terrible tragedy . </s>
it is really the loss of life that makes this particular disaster an extraordinary one by European standards . </s>
it is regrettable that we do not have any instrument with which to give assistance in situations like this . </s>
I want to thank the Commissioner for his comprehensive statement on the subject and his suggestion that we might indeed organise ourselves at European level to give assistance to Member States and regions that have tragedies like this . </s>
that is important . </s>
the other thing we should remember is that we did have a budget line in the past . </s>
it was very small . </s>
it was not able to do very much but it was repeatedly abused by Members of this House proposing action when the disasters were not even major . </s>
officials and ministers from Member States were coming to Brussels , whispering with the Commission and getting a few euros and making a political point by bringing aid back to their constituencies . </s>
so there was not much sympathy for this budget line when it was abolished . </s>
I think we should reinstate this budget line . </s>
when we had the earthquake in Greece , which was a big disaster , the Community had no instrument with which to offer its sympathy or solidarity to the Greeks . </s>
the same when the floods came in France and the same again now . </s>
these are major disasters , we should have an instrument , we do not have it . </s>
we should reinstate that instrument and we should make the rules tight so that only in situations where grave disasters occur will we call up this particular instrument . </s>
we can save it from year to year and ensure that when something major happens we have an instrument to deal with it . </s>
we did not have it so bad in Ireland this time although we have had many serious wind storms on the Atlantic . </s>
we had floods in Ireland also and I want to express my sympathy with the people in Ireland who suffered from these . </s>
ladies and gentlemen , none of us must forget what has taken place . </s>
it is true that there was a joint decision by the Council and Parliament seeking to discontinue emergency lines . </s>
it is also true that there is a lot of European money around . </s>
Commissioner Barnier has pointed out that oyster farming and agriculture would be eligible under Article 30 of the regulation concerning rural development , forestry would be eligible under Article 33 , companies would be eligible under exemptions from the competition law stated in Article 87 ( 2 ) of the Treaty and public facilities would be eligible under the Structural funds . </s>
it is nevertheless the case that not a penny more than what was allocated before the storm will now be freed up to demonstrate practical , active solidarity . </s>
it is nothing more than the States playing at taking from Peter in order to give to Paul . </s>
this is inadequate , and I am personally delighted that Mr Barnier has stated an idea close to my heart and which , moreover , I expressed when I told the press in Bordeaux what I am hoping for , and that is the establishment of a reinforced policy of European civil security . </s>
if the European citizenship that we all want to see is to come into being , if the mandate that our President , Mrs Fontaine has staked on a closer relationship between the Union and Europe 's citizens is to be effective , our citizens must be able to feel that we are acting with some urgency . </s>
I therefore believe that a European civil protection force , real civil relief blue helmets , who would go to areas in difficulty within the Union , as we currently have no emergency procedure , but also outside the Union if needs be , in Venezuela or anywhere else , is something that we should hope to see . </s>
I would like to tell Commissioner Barnier that in me he has an active ally for this idea which strikes me as noble and truly European in spirit . </s>
Mr President , Commissioner , when we compare the frequency with which storms occur in other parts of the world with our own situation , we see that Europe gets off relatively lightly . </s>
nevertheless , the storms that took place in the last week of December showed us what the consequences can be and that there are major problems in store for us . </s>
anyone travelling to Strasbourg by car or by rail would have been able to see for themselves that storms raged in Alsace as well . </s>
I would therefore like to extend my sympathy to all those citizens in the regions where the storms raged so furiously , and at the same time , from my position here in this Chamber , point to how important it is to support these regions and people . </s>
each and every one of us knows that any other region of Europe could meet with just such a fate tomorrow . </s>
what we need to do now is to deal with the fallen timber as swiftly as possible . </s>
for it is common knowledge that we could have an even greater disaster on our hands if the fallen timber were to be left in the forests too long . </s>
for instance , it should be pointed out that fallen timber provides the best breeding ground for the bark beetle 's larvae , and we are not yet in a position to assess the repercussions this will have . </s>
that is why it is absolutely essential to deal with the fallen timber before the warmer weather arrives . </s>
decades will have gone by before we are able to determine the true extent of the damage sustained by the forestry industry . </s>
for we all know how long it takes a tree to grow . </s>
the calculations are in decades rather than years . </s>
in addition , I would like to point out that the forestry industry is certainly not just about timber production , for barrier woodland and woodland that acts as a shield against avalanches also constitute an important factor in certain regions . </s>
I am therefore very proud to say that the skilled Austrian forestry workers are also prepared ... . </s>
. </s>
( the President cut the speaker off ) Mr President , I extend our deepest sympathy to all of those who were affected by the storms . </s>

Mr President , Commissioner , I second all those who expressed their solidarity with the storm victims . </s>

for the storms will have major implications for the forestry industry in all areas of Europe , and I believe we need , in the long-term , to give thought to how problems of this kind are to be dealt with in future . </s>
we certainly do not want market organisation for forests , but maybe we should set up a system , perhaps in conjunction with the private insurance sector , which will make it possible to mitigate the implications for the victims in some way . </s>

as has already been mentioned here , there are indications - no proof , but clear indications - that the increase in storms world-wide has to do with the climate catastrophe . </s>
of course , the scientists do not all see eye to eye on this yet , but the majority of them are fairly convinced that if we continue to emit greenhouse gases as we are doing , these storms will , of course , hit us much harder still at the dawn of this new century . </s>

he suggested that rather than giving storms the names of men or women , we should name them after the perpetrators of the greenhouse effect - he proposed the oil companies at the time . </s>

we must be aware of this connection ; I do not support those who make sweeping statements to the effect that the greenhouse effect is to blame for this storm , but one thing we can be relatively certain of is that we have reason to fear further catastrophes if we do not soon alter our course ! </s>
Mr President , I would first like to thank you for proposing to extend this debate in order to see it through . </s>

food safety the next item is the communication on food safety and a statement by the Commission . </s>
Mr President , I am very pleased to take this first available opportunity of outlining to Parliament the main lines of the Commission 's White Paper on food safety , adopted on Wednesday last , 12 January , in association with my colleague , Mr Liikanen . </s>
at my hearing last September , I promised speedy delivery of this White Paper . </s>
I am happy that we have been able to deliver so quickly . </s>
the White Paper represents three to four months of intensive work since the new Commission was appointed last September . </s>
it takes on board the extensive consultations of the past couple of years since the Commission 's Green Paper on food law was published . </s>
equally it reflects our experiences of recent food alerts in such areas as dioxin and sludge , as well as the BSE crisis . </s>
the White Paper also reflects the concerns of this Parliament which you have outlined to both President Prodi and myself on the numerous occasions we have debated food safety in this House since the Commission was appointed . </s>
I do not need to remind you that consumer confidence in Europe 's food safety regime has been badly affected by the crises and alerts of recent years and months . </s>
the Commission is fully committed to restoring that confidence by putting in place the most up-to-date and effective food safety regime in the world . </s>
when I launched the White Paper last week I said that the shopping trolley is one of the most potent weapons on the face of the earth . </s>
the most discerning decisions are made by the consumers of Europe . </s>
if their confidence is damaged this is reflected in shopping decisions . </s>
this in turn has a dramatic effect on farmers , producers and industry generally . </s>
in an industry worth some EUR 600 billion annually , even a slight dip in confidence levels can have significant effects . </s>
between the agro-food sector and the farming sector there are over 10 million employees . </s>
high levels of confidence are necessary to boost job numbers and competitiveness . </s>
this crisis of confidence has also had the unfortunate but inevitable effect of eroding the trust of consumers in the systems and institutions at national and European level that should monitor and assure the highest standards of food safety . </s>
in saying all of this , I would like to make it clear that Europe nevertheless has one of the best food industries in the world and also one of the safest food control systems . </s>
the challenge is to make the system the very best . </s>
the overall objective therefore of the White Paper on food safety is to put in place the necessary legislation and structures that will guarantee the highest possible level of health protection for consumers arising from the consumption of food . </s>
we are setting out a challenging and ambitious agenda for change . </s>
the Commission will need the full support of Parliament if we are to achieve our ambitions on schedule . </s>
we will also need the fullest support from the Council and other key stakeholders . </s>
the White Paper on food safety outlines a comprehensive range of actions needed to complement and modernise existing EU food legislation . </s>
all of these measures are designed to make it more coherent , understandable and flexible . </s>
we want to promote better enforcement of that legislation and to provide greater transparency to consumers . </s>
the detailed action plan on food safety in the White Paper sets a precise timetable for action over the next three years . </s>
over 80 measures are envisaged . </s>
our objective is to put in place a coherent and up-to-date body of food law by the end of 2002 . </s>
we are also envisaging the establishment of a European food authority by 2002 as an essential complement to the new food safety regime . </s>
this idea will be the focus of much scrutiny and debate . </s>
it has already attracted much comment , including reactions from Members of Parliament . </s>
the chapter of the White Paper devoted to the establishment of a European food authority is clearly designed to elicit views and comments . </s>
we are seeking views by the end of April on what we envisage . </s>
I will return to this process of consultation in a few moments . </s>
the Commission believes that major structural change is required in our system of food safety to ensure the twin objectives of assuring the highest standard of food safety and restoring consumer confidence . </s>
why should a European food authority be an essential part of that structure of change ? </s>
the first key concern is independence . </s>
key stakeholders , including consumers , are seeking a system that is independent and perceived to be independent of all vested interests . </s>
we must also ensure excellence and transparency . </s>
we have made a lot of progress over the past couple of years since the reformed system of scientific advice was adopted as a consequence of the BSE crisis . </s>
however , the Commission believes that we must go further . </s>
we must create a permanent and truly independent , excellent and transparent system of risk assessment . </s>
the key task of the authority will be risk assessment in the area of food safety . </s>
we envisage that the work of the existing five scientific committees devoted to food safety will be transferred to the authority . </s>
they may not be transferred in their present form or structure - this is an issue on which we will elicit views before making our definitive proposals on the authority 's establishment . </s>
however , if we were merely to propose a simple moving of deckchairs , this would clearly not be enough . </s>
as the White Paper makes clear , the new authority must be a value-added structure . </s>
I am of the view that the existing system of scientific advice needs to be strengthened . </s>
within the authority I envisage much stronger scientific and other support for the independent scientists . </s>
I am also envisaging that the authority will be much more proactive than our current regime - anticipate rather than react , identify issues before they become crises . </s>
this proactive approach should become the hallmark of the authority . </s>
to be proactive the White Paper identifies a number of new areas that would be embraced by the authority . </s>
these include a comprehensive information gathering and surveillance function , the coordination of scientific information in the EU , and building up strong networks with food safety agencies and bodies in Member States . </s>
as part of its remit we also envisage the authority operating an enhanced rapid alert system for food and feed concerns . </s>
the Commission has decided that it is neither appropriate nor feasible to devolve risk management power to the authority . </s>
we believe that decisions in the risk management area should properly remain the preserve of the Commission , Parliament and Council . </s>
I make no apology for this approach ; I firmly believe that it is the correct one . </s>
certainly there are those who would argue that we should give law-making powers to such an authority . </s>
I do not accept those views and reject them with some degree of passion . </s>
it was only last year that the Treaty was amended to give Parliament a much greater role in the legislative process . </s>
to give such a role to an authority at this stage would be , in my view , a retrograde step and represent a dilution of democratic accountability . </s>
I will be very interested to hear the views of Parliament itself in relation to this matter . </s>
there are also those who argue that the Commission could effectively ignore the advice of the new authority . </s>
I also reject this line of argument . </s>
how could a Commissioner for health and consumer protection reject or ignore well-founded independent scientific advice in relation to food safety ? </s>
would this be in the interests of Europe 's citizens ? </s>
in my view , most definitely not unless such rejection of the scientific arguments were soundly based , rationally argued and fully justified . </s>
it seems difficult to envisage such a situation evolving . </s>
I can assure you here today that the Commission , in exercising its risk management functions , will fully take account of the scientific advice of the authority . </s>
I have already said that the authority will be charged with developing networks with national food safety agencies and bodies in the Member States . </s>
this is a major task . </s>
we must develop greater certainty in the science that underpins food safety in the European Union . </s>
the authority must become the authoritative source of scientific advice and information on food safety issues . </s>
this situation will not come about by the very creation of the authority but will evolve over time as confidence is gained in the authority itself . </s>
I do not believe we can be prescriptive in the area of science and advice based on science . </s>
however , with the evolution of dynamic networks with national scientific bodies and agencies , the authority will become pre-eminent on the European stage . </s>
I am also anxious to hear the views of Parliament in this regard . </s>
as an integral part of a value-added structure , the White Paper proposes that the authority would have a major role in risk communication : to disseminate complex scientific information in a consumer-friendly way ; to be the obvious and indispensable port of call for the most up-to-the-minute data on risk ; to be highly visible ; to tell the good news story about food ; to be proactive . </s>
the White Paper also contains very important proposals in respect of controls . </s>
this is a hugely important component of the system of checks and balances to ensure that Member States and operators are complying with Community legislation . </s>
I want to see a genuine internal market operating in the control arena . </s>
in this context we are also proposing to strengthen significantly the control function carried out by the food and veterinary office located in Dublin . </s>
this revised Community framework would have three core elements : operational criteria set up at Community level , Community control guidelines , and enhanced administrative cooperation in the development and operation of control . </s>
as part of our proposals in this area - which I expect to bring forward at the end of this year - I will be examining whether additional powers in addition to infringement procedures need to be given to the Commission . </s>
these could include withholding Community financial support or recouping funding already committed to a Member State . </s>
these proposals must be seen as part of our mission to have the highest food safety standards in the world , boost consumer confidence and increase markets for farmers and producers in the Union . </s>
in addition to the proposals for a new European food authority and an enhanced control system at Community-level , the White Paper proposes an action plan with a wide range of measures to improve and bring coherence to the Community 's legislation , covering all aspects of food products from farm to table . </s>
it sets out over 80 separate actions that are envisaged over the period ahead and intends to close identified loopholes in current legislation . </s>
the new legal framework will cover animal feed , animal health and welfare , hygiene , contaminants and residues , novel food , additives , flavourings , packaging and irradiation . </s>
it will include a proposal on general food law which will embody the principles of food safety such as responsibility of feed manufacturers , farmers and food operators , traceability of feed , food and ingredients , proper risk analysis through , for instance , risk assessment - that is , scientific advice and information analysis - risk management - that is , regulation and control - risk communication , and application of the precautionary principle if and when appropriate . </s>
as regards the precautionary principle , I might add that the Commission is currently finalising a communication which I expect to be adopted very soon . </s>
I look forward to having a useful exchange of views this afternoon with the Members of Parliament who would clearly have preferred to do this last week if there had been an appropriate parliamentary forum available . </s>
however , having regard to my contacts with the presidents of the relevant committees , I recognise that this was not feasible . </s>
but I know too that we will have many further opportunities in the coming months to consider the White Paper 's proposals on the authority . </s>
we now have a number of months to have the necessary debate on the Commission 's ideas on the White Paper on the establishment of a European food authority . </s>
Parliament will have a key part to play in this debate . </s>
Parliament played a crucial role in Europe 's response to the BSE crisis . </s>
it has especially active since then in bringing citizens ' concerns about food safety issues to the fore . </s>
I expect that Parliament 's contribution to the debate on the authority can be as incisive and constructive . </s>
while we have a number of months to the end of April to debate the issue and garner our views , I recognise fully that this is also a very tight timeframe . </s>
I would therefore ask Parliament to make appropriate arrangements to ensure that its views can be formulated as quickly as possible . </s>
it is essential that the Commission should have the benefit of Parliament 's contribution to the shaping of what would be a key component of raising consumer health protection to a new plane and thereby restoring consumer confidence in the European Union 's food safety regime . </s>
the European food authority will be a key ingredient in the EU 's food safety regime in the years ahead . </s>
it is essential that we get the mix right . </s>
Mr President , I thank the Commissioner for his statement . </s>
I would like to welcome the division of labour that you have made and that food management will remain the responsibility of the European institutions , including the Commission and Parliament . </s>
that is very much the right approach . </s>
but there is one word that I have not heard you mention here tonight . </s>
I hope that we can thrash this out . </s>
we need a body of food law , as you have said , and we need to agree this together . </s>
it is very important that we include liability in that process . </s>
that is the one word I am talking about . </s>
the problem so far is that taxpayers paid when something went wrong . </s>
that cannot continue . </s>
when we have a crisis we have to clearly identify in advance that if there is a problem , those responsible are liable . </s>

the Member States would not accept a regulatory agency , so there is not very much point in your proposing one . </s>
some sectors of the food industry clearly need better regulation and that is clear on the issue of feed and animal feedingstuffs . </s>
however , as chairman of a committee which looks as though it will be concerning itself almost entirely with food over the next three years , I have to ask : if Europe has the safest food control system , as you have said , why do we need 24 new directives and regulations and 20 new amending directives ? </s>
