Madam President , my group was one of those which wanted to have a document allowing an exchange of views on the Commission 's strategic objectives within the group before this debate , instead of being reduced to an on-the-spot reaction in plenary . </s>
the main merit of the text of this communication is therefore the fact that it exists . </s>
we are also pleased to see certain statements and intentions which it contains and which Mr Prodi has just underlined and , in some cases , usefully clarified . </s>
the current globalisation process is - and I quote - ' exclusive rather than inclusive and has widened the inequalities ' . </s>
the European Union 's objective must therefore be to help define new ground rules within the Union and in international relations . </s>
clearly , many citizens are ' disenchanted and anxious ' about the lack of real and lasting solutions to basic problems , such as unemployment and social exclusion , which affect our very existence . </s>
this must be one of our absolute priorities . </s>
we do need to rethink many aspects of current Community policy if the important and difficult project of enlargement is to be a success . </s>
we also need ' distinctive strategic partnerships ' with our neighbours to the south and east in order to achieve stability and peace . </s>
there are plenty of areas for serious discussion . </s>
we will carefully study the planned White papers and will participate constructively in the work begun or promised . </s>
it is in this spirit that I have three criticisms to make . </s>
these must be taken into account if we are truly to shape the new Europe , as proclaimed ambitiously by the title of the Commission document and Mr Prodi 's speech and do so in reality not rhetoric . </s>
the first and most serious criticism concerns the Commission 's propensity for rather grandiloquent self-satisfaction with regard to the European Union and for a cursory and even condescending view of our partners . </s>
the perfect illustration of this crippling flaw lies in the opening sentence of the Commission communication . </s>
this talks of the European Union as ' living proof that peace , stability , freedom and prosperity can be brought to a continent ' and as a model showing the world the way forward . </s>
it concludes that ' our neighbours have the chance to join this prosperity , and we have a golden opportunity to enable them to do so ' . </s>
a more balanced and more rigorous diagnosis would be welcome in my view . </s>
similarly , the idea that the euro has fostered a consensus on wage moderation is not really borne out by the repeated nervous orders issued by the European Central Bank to the trade unions which are deemed to be too demanding . </s>
my second criticism follows on from the first . </s>
this extreme difficulty in seeing the contradictions of the current situation and , where necessary , confronting these is seriously limiting the will , duly confirmed by Mr Prodi , to grant public demands . </s>
for example , at least in the countries which I know well , I doubt that the intention , repeated three or four times in the Commission document , to reform ' Europe 's social protection , health care and pension systems ... in a climate of more cautious public spending ' will meet the needs of those whose confidence we apparently want to win back . </s>
my third criticism stems from the first two . </s>
the weakness of the analysis and the obstacles to the necessary changes have resulted in a project whose scope is severely limited by an overabundance of generalisations , a rather indecisive approach and therefore a lack of impetus . </s>
but all is not lost . </s>
this is a starting point and we have five years to succeed , provided that the political will exists and is expressed with sufficient force and clarity . </s>
my group is fully intent on helping with this work . </s>
Madam President , reforming and democratising the institutions of the European Union are central to the historic and moral challenge of the enlargement process . </s>
this was the opening statement of Commission President , Prodi , when he presented the strategic objectives of the European Commission for the next five years . </s>
we await the White Paper on the governance of the European Union dealing with the issue of balance between Member States ' governments and the European Union institutions which is to be published this summer . </s>
on this specific point I think it is important that we address the reform of the internal decision-making procedures of the Commission . </s>
the Commission , in its proposals to the forthcoming intergovernmental conference , has indicated that its preference lies in seeing smaller Member States lose their automatic right to nominate a member of the European Commission . </s>
this is a scenario whereby the European Union has a membership of over 25 Member States . </s>
I do not want to see a two-tier European Union built . </s>
I believe this would fly in the face of the spirit and objective of the Treaty of Rome and all subsequent treaties . </s>
there must be equality in terms of national representation within the Commission and within all the other European institutions . </s>
I would like to remind those who seek to eliminate the right of small Member States to nominate a European Commissioner that the United States of America gives smaller states the same recognition as larger states in the United States Senate . </s>
more or less each of the 50 states in the us has two elected positions in the United States Senate , regardless of its population . </s>
any future reforms of the European Union treaties will require a referendum to be held in my country . </s>
it would be very difficult for those who propose a ' yes ' vote in any such future treaty to win the support of the Irish people if we lose our right to have our nominee to the European Commission . </s>
undoubtedly , reform of the European Council is also going to be included in this White Paper on the governance of the European Union which will be published this summer . </s>
once again there are special areas of policy-making which should be left to the domain of the national Member States . </s>
I do not believe that there is broad support in Europe for the introduction of qualified majority voting on taxation , justice and home affairs , and foreign affairs at European Union level . </s>
at present , under Article 99 of the Treaty of Rome , decisions taken at EU level concerning tax changes must be by unanimity . </s>
I believe that this proposal should remain , as a common European taxation code would diminish rather than enhance the workings of the European Union . </s>
I support the enlargement of the European Union . </s>
I support institutional changes so as to ensure that enlargement of the Union takes place in a streamlined and structured manner . </s>
however , we must remember that the public opinion of 370 million people in the European Union is a vital factor in changing the EU treaties . </s>
changes should not be brought about too quickly and cannot be too sweeping , otherwise public opinion will make ratification of any future European Union treaty very difficult indeed . </s>
Madam President , I am speaking on behalf of the Italian radical Members . </s>
President of the Commission , a short while ago you said that no political structure sets out five-year plans . </s>
this is true , if we think of Russia 's plans in the thirties , but at the start of your mandate , a few months ago , you yourself announced at the Conference of Presidents that you would , however , be presenting a legislative programme , or rather , the major policy lines of the European government of which you are head and in the running of which we are engaged today . </s>
so , whether this is to be a government programme or a potential programme , the breakdown of the document you distributed to us and of the accompanying speech is not much more than a list of good intentions , or rather a list of issues on the table . </s>
it does not , however , give us the impression that the Commission is taking a clear position on any of these points , but that it is just doing the European Commission 's duty . </s>
in this House , in the past , large-scale debates have taken place on major strategic options which the Commission , under its power of initiative , launched , not as experiments , but as proposals which then made varying degrees of progress , but in any case did contribute to the integration and development of the European Union . </s>
in this case , Mr Prodi , we certainly have a kind of " ten Commandments " : a whole raft of issues are listed , but if I may say so , we are left with the impression that the Commission is afraid to make any decision regarding what needs to be done about any of these points . </s>
there was only one point that you really stressed - too much in my opinion - and that was that it looks almost as if the highest priority task that you are setting yourself is to cease " unnecessary " activities . </s>
we should be careful , though , Mr Prodi , because we had a crisis of confidence in the previous Commission and backed this Commission - at least a parliamentary majority backed this Commission - precisely because , first and foremost , the reform of the Commission would bring consolidation , a new identity and a new awareness of being guided by a firm hand . </s>
let us consider the scenario whereby the Commission , not believing itself to be equal to the task , wishes , or proposes to shed , for example , its powers to implement common policies , which it is nevertheless accorded by the Treaty . </s>
what do we expect from a government in any case ? </s>
what do we ask of this structure - the European Community - which is , so to speak , ambiguous and unique ? </s>
it is right for joint resources to be controlled supranationally and not to be delegated to the Member States or the TAOs , as has been the case in the past . </s>
it seems that you are proposing the same old menu , but with more unsatisfactory implications , restricting the Commission , so you say , to the task of drawing up a few White papers , as you proposed . </s>
my fear - even if you shake your head , Mr Prodi - is that this will translate into what some countries have thought for years , that the Commission should be a simple secretariat for the Council of Ministers . </s>
if this is the role that the Commission intends to play over the next five years , we federalists are convinced , we are certain that this is not the right path to take and we shall send for you and judge what the Commission intends to do in this regard . </s>
the reform is important but , if it aggravates the situation , reduces or weakens the supranational powers of the Commission , then the structure of European integration , as planned by the founding fathers for the European Commission , will be at risk . </s>
as for the other points , Mr Prodi , I will take economic and social policy as an example : the European social model is certainly experiencing a major crisis and it is certainly not coincidental that unemployment tops the list of problems that none of our policies has managed to resolve , but it is not certain that it can be resolved by going through a list of problems that we have discussed in the past , without having a clear idea or proposal which takes note of the fact that Europe contains economies that are growing at some of the most sustainable rates and that it is not by chance that these are the economies which have made labour market flexibility and enterprise their prime objective . </s>
if we continue to get bogged down with proposals that have given extremely poor results so far , I do not know what we or the Commission will be able to do . </s>
the same goes for enlargement as an end in itself , without it being linked to a reform to make the European Union and its structures much more efficient , and to proposals that the Commission could have made at the IGC . </s>
Mr Prodi , there is one positive thing that I would like to say to you , perhaps contrary to the opinion of some Members , regarding the telegram that you sent to the Austrian Government . </s>
we approve of your position on this : you did well not to isolate that country any further . </s>
in any case , we shall see what specific steps transpire when the time comes for practical action . </s>
Mr Prodi , I repeat that this is , in our opinion , a slightly short-sighted view . </s>
above all , it lacks drive in the sectors I have mentioned , for example , as regards the Balkans . </s>
can we really continue to leave the Balkans out of the enlargement process , disregarding the fact that Croatia , Macedonia and other countries also have the right to a place in this House that is open to all ? </s>
Madam President , Mr Prodi , I should like to applaud your proposal for a radical decentralisation of the Union 's activities and ask why , then , you are proposing a legislative programme which would lead to centralisation . </s>
I remember your predecessor 's speech five years ago . </s>
like yourself , he promised " less and better " , but Mr Santer finished up by having delivered " much more and much worse " , and I do not believe that you , either , can deliver the goods you promise . </s>
you talk about decentralisation but practise centralisation . </s>
the legislative programme is , in fact , a litany of subjects over which the people are to be deprived of influence and in connection with which , Mr Prodi , you are to take influence away from the people , even on social questions . </s>
you talk about greater transparency , but produce proposals which would lead to documents which , at present , are available for public inspection being locked away . </s>
your Commission consists of the only 20 people in the EU who can propose that the quantity of legislation should be reduced . </s>
local politicians cannot do that , once legislation has been passed in Brussels . </s>
the legislative programme from the Commission ought at least , therefore , to be accompanied by as long a list of tasks which are to be referred back to the Member States and to the processes of popular democracy . </s>
otherwise , the number of laws produced in Brussels will just keep on growing . </s>
we have passed 10 000 laws and as many amendments , and the applicant States have had 26 000 documents sent to them which , as debated by the Polish parliament , fill 140 000 sides of paper . </s>
even by this stage , that is already too many by far . </s>
Brussels should make decisions on fewer matters and hand over more decisions to the people , the regions and the Member States . </s>
the only decisions which should remain with Brussels are those concerning cross-border issues which the national parliaments can no longer legislate on effectively . </s>
what is more , the work carried out in Brussels should be of a much higher quality and be completely transparent , so that people might at least have some small sense of owning the process , now that Mr Prodi and his predecessor have taken their autonomy away from them . </s>
I should also just like to draw Mr Dell ' Alba 's attention to what the founding fathers of the European Union dreamed of . </s>
take a look at Jean Monet 's memoirs . </s>
what he envisaged was what he called a small , practical secretariat . </s>
that is not what Mr Prodi is President of today . </s>
Madam President , this morning the Commission President , Mr Prodi , has set out ambitious goals for the European Union for the next five years , laudable aims indeed , to make a strong and effective European presence felt in the world : succeeding with enlargement , meeting the challenge of selling e-Europe , introducing better principles of governance . </s>
we accept that Europeans , particularly the younger generation , need to be given a broad perspective of where Europe will be in the years ahead . </s>
but how are we to succeed when the resources available are limited and the credibility of our institutions is not very high ? </s>
we need to match this vision with reality . </s>
here there are three elements I would like to contribute . </s>
firstly , we need a successful European economy . </s>
we must ensure that unemployment rates continue to go down across Europe , confirm the trend in privatisation and deregulation , encourage the insertion of information technology and knowledge of the Internet , show that e-Europe is a good initiative . </s>
but we must avoid lurching back into the old-style regulation , stifling individual initiative and enterprise . </s>
we must not fear globalisation , but we must also make sure that we understand its political impact in the network society . </s>
without a successful European economy we cannot meet the challenges ahead , particularly of enlargement . </s>
secondly , we need to ensure that we legislate only when necessary - subsidiarity . </s>
doing less but better - a central plank of the last Commission - needs to be the aim of this Commission too . </s>
we will be looking at this closely when we come to the annual programmes of proposed legislation . </s>
Mr Bonde was right to say that there is this image of doing less better and then suddenly we see an annual programme for the year 2000 of 500 proposals and recommendations , which seems to go in a different direction . </s>
we must establish priorities and make sure there is value for money in each of these programmes . </s>
lastly , we need to ensure that there is proper , genuine reform of the European Commission . </s>
yes , the Commission - guardian of the Treaties - is meant to be an independent body , but it also has to be accountable to European citizens through our Parliament . </s>
the information problem , which Mr Bonde just referred to , is treated like a straw in the wind , with the Commission seeming to restrict information to us , as citizens and as parliamentarians , although we have the right to it under the Treaties . </s>
the Commission is not in fact today a European government . </s>
the Commission does not reflect the majority in this particular Parliament . </s>
we in Parliament have a major role to play in the shaping of governance in Europe . </s>
this governance therefore needs to be a sensitive governance so that we can actually work together and understand that each of the institutions in the European Union , has its relevant role to play . </s>
therefore we need to have credibility , coherence and confidence that in working together we can restore the image of the European Union to our citizens . </s>
Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , numerous steps have been taken in the past to strengthen the European Union , from the euro to resolutions on a common security policy ; even to the response by the 14 , the Commission and Parliament to the new coalition in Austria . </s>
I fully endorse the philosophy and the principles behind these decisions . </s>
nonetheless , I agree with you , Mr President of the Commission , that many more steps to strengthen the European Union will be needed in the future because the European Union is not strong enough either to master the huge , inevitable task of enlargement or to control current and potential movements which , to put it mildly , have an ambivalent attitude towards European values of democracy and tolerance and the desire to integrate all the people on our continent . </s>
that does not apply to Austria alone . </s>
the Union professes its faith in its fundamental values in the Treaty of Amsterdam and the institutions of the EU confirmed this faith once again when the new coalition was formed in Austria . </s>
however , the full potential of these values will only be realised if they are set out in comprehensive detail in and form part of the Treaty and , in the final analysis , represent legal claims on the part of individual citizens . </s>
when it comes down to it , Articles 6 and 7 of the Treaty are not enough . </s>
in this sense , the Commission must insist , and I should like to endorse and confirm this here , that the new Charter of fundamental rights become part of the Treaty and create binding , enforceable rights . </s>
in this sense , the Commission must insist on building up the common area of freedom , security and justice and in this sense I disagree with the last two speakers . </s>
only reasonable , feasible and humane principles of immigration and asylum law can counter the irrational , misleading and demagogic allegations of the extreme right . </s>
but , and I would like to stress this , this policy must also be accompanied by a coherent and convincing policy to promote employment and prevent social exclusion because unemployment , marginalisation and growing inequality are the best breeding grounds for anti-European , nationalistic actions and reactions . </s>
in this respect , Mr President of the Commission , I too should like to address the issue of globalisation which you speculated on and how it is perceived by large segments of the population . </s>
the feeling of being at the mercy of others , of lacking in influence and of having no protection from the state leads in the best case scenario to a lack of interest in politics and a refusal to vote , as in the European elections and , in the worst case scenario , to extremist voting patterns . </s>
the Union , like everyone else , has not yet understood how to present the EU to the citizens of the EU as a means of protection against the negative effects of globalisation . </s>
we are in the process of building a house but too few of our citizens really feel at home in our house . </s>
what we need are not just reforms of the world trade Organisation and the economic architecture - and , significantly , the President of the Commission forgot to mention the reform of the financial institutions and international financial architecture ; we also need confidence-building measures for our citizens , who rightly expect help and support from and in the EU with the inevitable and painful process of adapting to new global circumstances . </s>
in this respect , what the Commission says about boosting Europe 's voice is important . </s>
you yourself , Mr President , spoke of a model of which , unfortunately , there is little mention in the document . </s>
you said that we must offer our citizens a model of economic , social , cultural and ecological development , both internally and towards the outside world , which differs from other models , including the us model . </s>
in this sense , the USA is not only our partner ; it is also our competitor ; not our opponent , our competitor and we must fight to see which of us offers our citizens the best model . </s>
I hope that what we have said so clearly and vehemently here today will also be reinforced in the Commission documents . </s>
Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , the greatest legacy which your Commission could pass on to the European Union would be to help resettle and redistribute the increasingly jumbled and confused powers and competences of the Commission , and perhaps of the Union itself . </s>
you have made a bold start by rightly emphasising the need to focus on so-called " core tasks " . </s>
that , as you have said yourself today , means that you must also identify tasks , policies and programmes which are peripheral or irrelevant to the Commission 's main vocation . </s>
many existing European Union policies and programmes may simply have passed their sell-by date , or have been proved unwieldy or ineffective when administered at European level . </s>
the challenge now is to have the courage to devolve as many non-core tasks as possible back to lower levels of national , regional and local government . </s>
if we are to succeed in persuading a sceptical European public of the merits of further European integration , we must be able to demonstrate that we are as active in the devolution of unwarranted EU powers as we are in the evolution of new EU powers . </s>
we must not allow the critics of European integration to claim , as they presently do with some justification as we have just heard from Mr Bonde , that the increase in EU responsibilities is a one-way street only . </s>
it must be shown to be a two-way process in which existing EU policies and programmes , which are not clearly justified on the grounds of subsidiarity and proportionality , are devolved and repealed . </s>
if you are able to match these aspirations with actions in the years ahead , you will be making an unprecedented contribution to the future of the European Union as a whole and , as we have heard today , you will enjoy widespread support in this European Parliament . </s>
Madam President , Mr Prodi , I fully support the thinking of the proposals made by my colleague , Mrs Hautala , on the Commission 's strategic objectives for the coming five years . </s>
I myself want to refer to a subject which has not been mentioned but which is on the agenda , namely the Commission 's work programme for 2000 . </s>
I am aware of the limitations of the exercise given that we have to work within the current Treaty and are therefore restricted by its operational rules . </s>
I am thinking in this respect of the important issue of taxation which I am not , however , going to talk about . </s>
rather , I want to start by welcoming certain proposals which you have made in this programme for 2000 . </s>
these include all the proposals on food safety which are ambitious and important and those on maritime safety which are particularly important given the two oil slicks which have affected the coast of Brittany and Turkey . </s>
the Commission should react quickly in this respect . </s>
however , on other issues the proposals could be more ambitious and faster acting . </s>
I have some positive suggestions to make , particularly on the social area , the environment and the follow-up to Seattle . </s>
firstly , you have said that the citizens of Europe must be reconciled with the institutions . </s>
this is self-evident and it is therefore essential to find out their main concerns . </s>
for example , in the social area , it is not enough to announce a communication on a programme of social action . </s>
we must move faster . </s>
you must submit a new social action programme to us by the end of the year . </s>
the issue of company closures and mass redundancies is one which has been and still is very firmly in the news . </s>
we are working on the basis of a directive whose limitations have been clearly demonstrated . </s>
I therefore propose that this should be reviewed in order to produce a directive which is more effective in protecting employment and also in imposing penalties on those who do not comply . </s>
on the environment , you have announced a proposal for a decision on a sixth action programme on the environment . </s>
this is all very well but it seems that the text to be proposed will not contain any specific objectives or a timetable for implementation . </s>
perhaps you can correct me on this . </s>
I personally feel that it is essential to have precise objectives and a proper timetable for implementation . </s>
in terms of civil liability for the environment , it is right that we finally have a White Paper . </s>
however , Parliament did ask for a legislative initiative six years ago . </s>
the White Paper clearly foreshadows this legislation but for when ? </s>
you must realise that this process needs to be accelerated . </s>
finally , after Kyoto , we should be able to rapidly produce precise proposals . </s>
finally , on the subject of the WTO , the idea of relaunching a new global round is not necessarily bad . </s>
however , in the first place , the Commission should make proposals on changing the operational rules of the WTO . </s>
the Commission has a role both within the EU and throughout the world . </s>
the European Union must therefore instigate a re-evaluation of the WTO 's operation which must lead to precise proposals being made on its rules . </s>
Madam President , you spoke about fundamental political values , and one of the fundamental political values , even more important than democracy , is respect for others . </s>
we therefore feel that you acted correctly in sending a message and that perhaps those who protested about it are still feeling the effects of Bolshevism or Nazism . </s>
democracy means dialogue with others and making others realise when they are wrong , but also listening to their explanations . </s>
enlargement - and Alleanza Nazionale has been repeating this for ten years in this House - must not mean dilution , that is , it must not entail more risks . </s>
the applicant countries ' hopes are at least as important as the hopes of our current fellow citizens , who are beginning to feel bitterly disappointed by the way Europe works , as it is not resolving the most serious problems . </s>
we therefore need to be strict in the enlargement process and respect those agreements which - should it be necessary - need to be redrafted with regard to certain fundamental issues such as the environmental disaster that has occurred in Romania , reaching as far as Belgrade , but above all , the continuing spread of apathy as regards major security issues . </s>
even today , we do not have definite answers regarding the monitoring of the nuclear power stations in the eastern republics . </s>
we therefore need resources available to spend before proceeding to enlargement , so that we can at last establish a European monitoring body responsible for monitoring quality of life and living conditions , with the aim of creating a new world where such tragedies will no longer occur . </s>
I would also like to say a few words on Africa , Madam President . </s>
the third and fourth worlds have been abandoned : just one dollar , one and a half euro would be enough to save a great many children . </s>
Europe , which is so democratic , so progressive , does not speak out or take these tragic problems on board , while half of Africa is dying of AIDS and other diseases . </s>
one final remark regarding the Internet and globalisation . </s>
globalisation of the economy must not be reduced to product and quality certification , just as the globalisation of politics must not come to mean levelling of values or dampening of hopes and enthusiasm . </s>
the peoples which do not participate and gradually grow more distant will leave the way open for an oligarchy that will take power and leave control in the hands of a few . </s>
as for the Internet , Europe has finally found the courage to say that we need rules . </s>
on a personal note , please allow me at this time to congratulate the pirates who , by acting the way they are , are forcing the world to reflect on the only system which is currently unregulated . </s>
we live in a world of rules and regulations : let us regulate the Internet too and give our fellow citizens rules and hope for the future . </s>
Madam President , as a Padanian taxpayer , I have already experienced the vice-like grip of the taxman and former Prime Minister of Italy , Mr Prodi , since Padania is liable to Italy for its taxes as well . </s>
listening to him just now , I was concerned when he mentioned new resources , something that readily translates as additional taxation , in view , inter alia , of enlargement , that is the entry of new States into the Union . </s>
but why do they not buy their own entrance ticket ? </s>
my Padanian electorate who , thanks to Mr Prodi , have already paid what in Italy is known as the European tax - repaid only in part - have absolutely no intention , thanks once again to Mr Prodi , of paying another tax for someone else . </s>
Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , Members of the Commission , five months after its coming into office , the Commission committed to paper the direction in which it aims to steer the European Union . </s>
the ensuing document is both ambitious and bombastic . </s>
is it not rather melodramatic to say that " the world looks up to Europe " ? </s>
moreover , Europe as a continent is a great deal more than just the fifteen EU Member States . </s>
it is not rather ambitious to ensure peace , democracy and human rights in the whole of Europe , no less ? </s>
I am particularly intrigued by how the Commission considers bringing this about . </s>
does " the European integration model as a rich source for global administration " imply the export of a large-scale perspective and concentration of power ? </s>
according to the Commission , external policy can succeed , provided everyone knows exactly who is in charge ! </s>
so who is this then ? </s>
the Commission as a whole , its President perhaps , the Council ? </s>
you stated that the new European government requires strong institutions , while the Commission wants to focus at the same time on its core tasks . </s>
we could not agree more with the latter . </s>
it is high time that institutions restricted their scope to actual cross-border issues and stopped decking out the European cart with powers which they are taking away from national authorities . </s>
the document mentions common values on different occasions . </s>
unfortunately , I find the reference to the relevant standards to be lacking . </s>
this raises the question as to what these standards and values are based on . </s>
I am convinced that the Bible , God 's word , is the only pure source of proper standards and real values . </s>
in the tradition of our continent , this realisation is an important one which merits recognition . </s>
Madam President , I would like to congratulate Mr Prodi and the Commission on their government policy statement . </s>
I very much agree with the gist of the document . </s>
I also share the view of Mr Prodi and the Commission that in a number of areas , there is a need for more Europe and more integration , and rightly so . </s>
areas such as security , the world trade Conference , food safety , but also the new economy , require more action , therefore , from the European Commission . </s>
it will be a challenge to find a way of bringing the Member States , the Council , the European Parliament , the national parliaments , the Commission and all kinds of other agents into line . </s>
the European Commission will need to play an important director 's role in this , provided that clear and attainable objectives are in place . </s>
clear priorities , focus , and , above all , communication with society to inform them of what we are up to , are the key goals . </s>
that requires from the Commission , with a view to subsidiarity , concrete plans which we would like to see implemented in the forthcoming programmes . </s>
there is , in itself , nothing wrong with emphasising the core functions , and I applaud the fact that the Commission would like to assume a better , more prominent role in order to develop policy ideas and political initiatives . </s>
but what also matters is the actual implementation of the Commission 's ideas . </s>
take the Telecom sector , for example . </s>
although we have drafted a large number of directives , at the end of the day , we still have 15 different markets and the 15 Member States still implement the directives differently . </s>
and where implementation is concerned , the Commission needs to ensure that our political wishes are also implemented in practice . </s>
looking at foreign policy , Madam President , I very much like the ambition that the European Union should have as much political as economic say at world level . </s>
but then I wonder : if there is talk of a real common policy , of a system of crisis prevention and crisis control at Community level , where are the actual proposals then ? </s>
indeed , at the end of the day , we need these in order to verify whether we can realise our objectives in this area . </s>
Mr Prodi was right in devoting a lot of attention to Africa in his speech , but I have to say that I am nonetheless disappointed when I study the work programme for 2000 . </s>
I cannot find any reference to Africa in the introduction , nor in the programme itself , and I do hope , therefore , that Mr Prodi will produce a proper file by way of preparation of the Summit in Africa . </s>
Madam President , words are essential , but we can only judge the Commission on its merits . </s>
Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , ladies and gentlemen , I am not sure which to go by : the strategic objectives for 2000 to 2005 or your speech for 2000 to 2010 ? </s>
have you already included your second term of office ? </s>
but seriously . </s>
as it enlarges , the Union needs to be strengthened through streamlining and demarcation . </s>
first , streamlining . </s>
what you say in your programme about concentrating on the core functions of the Commission is only the beginning . </s>
the activities of the entire Union must be reduced to core areas of policy . </s>
in other words , a social , ecologically-orientated market , a secure currency , guaranteed civil rights internally and representation of common interests externally . </s>
it is not just that we need to speak out in the world with one voice ; it is what we want to say with this voice that it is important . </s>
secondly , the new " in " word is flexibility . </s>
however , increasing flexibility can or quickly threatens to turn into intergovernmentalisation . </s>
we must hold fast to joint decision-making institutions which embrace the Member States . </s>
that also applies to the inclusion of the civil society , which is a welcome step . </s>
our citizens do not need any new institutions and certainly no new mixing of powers . </s>
( Applause ) transparency does not mean more access to more paper ; to our citizens , transparency means greater clarity at long last as to who takes decisions in Brussels and Strasbourg , when and with what right . </s>
that is transparency . </s>
thirdly , the European Union cannot and should not enlarge endlessly . </s>
its borders are set not by how may countries want to join , but by how many countries it can accommodate . </s>
( Applause ) if the price of enlargement is the watering-down or even the break-up of the present Union , then it must not be paid . </s>
it is too high a price , not only for the Member States already in the Union but also for the states which want to join the Union . </s>
there is no future for a Union which is merely a geo-strategic concept or for a Union which is merely a free trade zone . </s>
but the Union will only continue to be more than a market and to be accredited by the people of Europe if it sees itself as a community of destinies . </s>
that goes far beyond your new economic and social agenda or a new , better quality of life . </s>
not only the Commission , not only the European Parliament but also the people and the states in our European Union will have to find new answers to the question of how and why we want to live and work together . </s>
in doing so , we need , no less , to reinvent the European Union , but without destroying the present Union . </s>
( Applause ) Madam President , in the opinion of the Group of the European Liberal Democrat and reform Party , the most important task of the Commission and the whole Union in the coming years is the successful realisation of enlargement . </s>
the Commission must carry on negotiations that are a decisive attempt to have each applicant country join the Union as soon as possible . </s>
on the other hand , we have to see to it that none of the achievements or aims of integration that have been stated thus far are watered down . </s>
to avoid this the European Liberal Democrats have expressed the hope that the Intergovernmental Conference will consider the various models of differentiated integration and create a concentric Union , in which there is a federal core and a less integrated outer ring . </s>
it is clear that the subject of the internal differentiation of the Union will be raised at the IGC . </s>
the subject needs to be discussed without prejudice . </s>
a technical improvement in the flexibility system will not be enough : we also have to raise the issue of developing our institutions for the countries in the vanguard as proposed by Jacques Delors , for example . </s>
in this way , a decision-making system can be created that is more effective , clearer , more open and more democratic . </s>
I hope that the Commission will make its own proposal concerning how the expanding Union might implement its institutional and other differentiation . </s>
Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , Commissioners , your inspiring speech , Mr Prodi , has quite won me over . </s>
it raises expectations , but it can also lead to disappointment . </s>
this is connected to what Mr Van Velzen was just saying , about the difference between words and deeds . </s>
the enlargement of the Union is inspired by our wish for peace , security and stability . </s>
you are looking to reassure the acceding countries , as well as European opinion . </s>
but these days , we are witnessing the exact reverse before our very eyes . </s>
we have noted increasing levels of apprehension and disquiet , even within regions where unemployment is quite low and prosperity very high . </s>
we need to make our citizens feel at home , according to Mr Swoboda , and I agree . </s>
this is a place where we share the same values and where each and one of us also have our own task and responsibility . </s>
this is probably linked to the standards mentioned by Mr Van Dam , namely subsidiarity . </s>
it is necessary to have a clear division of responsibility among all levels of authority and to be partners , rather than competitors when it comes to policy . </s>
it is also necessary to exercise authority as closely as possible to the citizens , where it can be exercised with due transparency and can be monitored by the citizens themselves . </s>
that will require a new political culture , not only in words , but also in practice , which will take into consideration the reality of Member States and regions . </s>
regions which , culturally and economically , sometimes match the interest of some Member States . </s>
the new Europe should not only expand horizontally , but also vertically , by living by our values in practice and by developing a democratic structure of a real community . </s>
this is what the Commission will be judged on . </s>
Madam President , the Commission is today presenting its strategic objectives for 2000-2005 . </s>
these are contained in an extremely general document in which all the problems have been glossed over to prevent any conflict . </s>
so , in the first part on the new forms of European governance , the words ' federalism ' and ' superstate ' are not mentioned at all . </s>
yet these are the main themes in any discussion of strong European institutions in which only day-to-day tasks of execution are decentralised and a collective vision is promoted within an indistinct whole . </s>
in this scenario the governments and national parliaments are merged with the regional and even local authorities and with the civil society , all of which are described , with no form of hierarchy , as ' integral elements of European governance ' . </s>
these ambiguities mask many misunderstandings , primarily about our values . </s>
it is not enough to claim to adhere to democracy in order to be a democrat . </s>
it must clearly be accepted that the people should be free to make their decisions at the level which best combines the objective conditions of an immediate , fair and transparent democratic debate , namely at national level in the main . </s>
yet the whole of the Commission communication is based on the opposite theory . </s>
in this theory , on the pretext of ensuring the best protection for peoples , their margin of independent choice should be increasingly limited by new regulations , new policies or new , restrictive legal structures such as the draft Charter of fundamental rights . </s>
this Charter is really misnamed because it will actually reduce these rights . </s>
in the Union for a Europe of Nations Group our principles are rather different . </s>
clearly we want to defend the countries of Europe but we also want to respect the autonomy of nations . </s>
this is not impossible . </s>
we must move away from the outmoded federalist schemes promoted by those whose every idea on European matters comes from the Memoires of Jean Monnet . </s>
instead , we must open the European institutions to the modern world by creating a flexible dynamic which respects nations . </s>
this is the keynote idea on the new governance which we would have liked to have seen in your communication , Mr Prodi , but which is unfortunately not there . </s>
Madam President , Mr Prodi , you claim to be shaping a new Europe yet you are lacking one basic element : confidence . </s>
the confidence of millions of Europeans cannot be won without being worthy of this . </s>
and how could you be worthy of this after the mad cow scandal and the resignation of the Santer Commission for corruption ? </s>
you are responsible for millions of unemployed and for millions living in poverty , insecurity and increasing misery because of your ultra-trade-oriented and ultra-liberal policies and because of the forced march towards the single currency . </s>
you wanted and have obtained the abolition of internal borders . </s>
consequently , you have opened Europe up to an explosion in crime and insecurity and to a flood of uncontrolled immigration . </s>
you are now proposing to give all decision-making power to a handful of officials . </s>
the Member States , local authorities and NGOs will simply become enforcers of decisions handed down from above , all on an equal footing in their submission to Brussels . </s>
not once does your twelve-page document mention the national parliaments even though they comprise the elected representatives of the people . </s>
clearly , they have no role to play in your strategy . </s>
you dare not even call a spade a spade , but instead hide behind pseudo-trendy language by using the term ' governance ' for what is nothing more than federal , autocratic , centralised government . </s>
having tried for many years to persuade us by talking of shared sovereignty , you are now revealing your ultimate goal . </s>
you intend to trade in all European sovereignty , whether national or collective , for a world government in which you do not even expect to obtain a dominant position . </s>
finally , you are daring to condemn and penalise the free and democratic vote of millions of Austrians , or are allowing this to happen , just because the result does not suit you . </s>
yet at the same time you are supporting Communist China and trading with countries which have openly violated human rights for decades . </s>
Members of this House are today speaking out against a telegram from Mr Prodi to Chancellor Schüssel which , quite obviously , is not a demonstration of sympathy but rather a political manoeuvre . </s>
your sabre-rattling fools no one because , as you know perfectly well , whether you like it or not , you need Austria in order to reform the Treaties and harmonise savings tax . </s>
you will cynically and hypocritically use Austria as a convenient threat to further strip the Member States of any real powers in the construction of the European Union . </s>
your Commissioners are clearly not solely responsible for this . </s>
the governments which , through spinelessness or ideology , support you are also responsible . </s>
Brussels is not all of us , as you claim . </s>
it is all of you . </s>
tell the truth for once . </s>
you could not care less what the people of Europe want . </s>
they are free to choose only between your brave new world and denouncement . </s>
it is over ten years since the collapse of the Soviet Union and yet your projects contain a strong hint of the gulags and mollifying moralism . </s>
we were among the small number who denounced the communist dictatorship . </s>
we are and will remain among those fighting against Europeanist dictatorship . </s>
we call on all the people of Europe to resist your monstrous projects . </s>
the salvation of European democracies is with nation states . </s>
Europe 's salvation lies in the cooperation of the nations of Europe . </s>
( limited applause ) President Prodi , today you have presented the Commission 's five-year programme , and it has many objectives that we endorse . </s>
it is a programme based on real-life situations and issues , and it is therefore right to put concrete measures aside for the moment and focus on the major issues . </s>
in my view , Mr Prodi , judging from the text and the document that you had sent to us , one subject that is very important to both of us has been given secondary importance , and that is solidarity , not so much at international level as at internal level . </s>
the Archbishop of Milan , Monsignor Carlo Maria Martini , is calling upon all politicians , in particular those like you and me , President Prodi , for whom the cultural and historic principle behind their presence in politics is the principle of the active involvement of Catholics in politics , to reconsider a development process , which , in addition to economic profit , takes the marginalised and those left behind by society very much into account . </s>
it is of the utmost importance to address the issue of those who cannot keep up , one which reminds us of how difficult and complicated it is to establish progress indicators and how inadequate it is to use the parameter of per capita income alone . </s>
it also reminds us of the need for a new growth model , one that is firmly rooted in the culture of the Catholics who are involved in social problems , who see , in the civil community and the social interaction that that must be encouraged and facilitated among the public , the most natural instruments for building solidarity . </s>
the fundamental element for the development of each person - his freedom , which comes before economic gain - is thus enhanced . </s>
this social freedom , which becomes manifest in initiatives favouring the poor , gives excellent results in terms of social justice and stability . </s>
Mr President , public institutions must not accept only the economic criterion . </s>
they must focus on service to people and commitment to achieving freedom for each individual , without forgetting , naturally , that all this cannot and must not conflict with the need to create business , to invest and risk , and in an ordered and focused system , entrepreneurs are able to make a substantial contribution to social growth solidarity . </s>
in the age of globalisation , which we do want to facilitate with a framework of specific rules that will provide guarantees to the economic operators and consumers , the European Commission cannot forget solidarity , and must call for its implementation through the use of all of man 's spiritual resources in his relations with his fellow man . </s>
our heritage has taught us that politics must have a heart . </s>
we hope that the White Paper and the actions of you and your Commission will put this into practice . </s>
Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , ' shaping the new Europe ' is an ambitious objective both for the Commission and for us all . </s>
our ambitions and our work will be followed not only by people in our own countries , but also by many people outside Europe and the European Union . </s>
what sort of impression will an interested public , as well as the rest of the world , have of this five-year programme ? </s>
my reply would be : a new start , a clear agenda for reform which confirms that the Union in the 2000s will not stop at being an economic community but will become a community that can be trusted and that we take seriously . </s>
the Commission is correct in stating that the Union intends to develop and safeguard the welfare state in an age of globalisation . </s>
it foresees a just and more effective Europe that also recognises its responsibilities beyond its own borders out of solidarity and enlightened self-interest . </s>
consequently , we see poverty and exclusion as the greatest enemies of peace and freedom . </s>
I concur with what other members of my political group have said and I commend the tone of your document . </s>
however , there are two omissions which need to be addressed in our future work . </s>
the first concerns women , gender and women 's rights . </s>
you talked about how women can help in increasing production and growth . </s>
that is important , but equality is not only necessary for productivity , but also to make our societies more democratic . </s>
it is therefore noticeable that ' equality ' , ' gender ' and ' women ' are barely mentioned in ' shaping the new Europe ' . </s>
you mentioned ' women ' in your speech , but they are not referred to in the context of the strategic goals . </s>
is that because mainstreaming is already so widespread in the Commission that there is no need to mention women ? </s>
what other explanation could there be for omitting women ? </s>
the EU must not take on a masculine persona . </s>
my other question concerns Africa , which is the only continent not mentioned in ' shaping the new Europe ' . </s>
Africa has the largest number of refugees in the world , the most overall poverty and a debilitating AIDS epidemic . </s>
I know that Commissioner Nielson and some of the other Commissioners are doing a fine job , but the rest of the Commission also needs to focus more clearly on that continent , partly by including it among its strategic goals . </s>
finally , I welcome the Commission 's statement and the fact that this says for the first time that the EU is prepared unilaterally to introduce measures to make it easier for developing countries to gain access to our markets . </s>
I would merely ask when this is likely to take effect . </s>
Madam President , President of the Commission , this is a vital document for the future and fate of Europe . </s>
however , out of all the points , two specifically require our attention , and they are closely linked : peace and stability within Europe and outside Europe . </s>
it is a question of objectives that must be pursued as a priority . </s>
for some time , we have all agreed on this notion , but we must also clearly affirm that these objectives will not be achieved without enlargement , even if this comes at a price . </s>
today , we have been called on to choose , for the forthcoming decades , between a Europe that might be less prosperous but a beacon of peace and civilisation for the whole planet and a Europe that might be more wealthy , but where there is uncertainty over what the future might bring . </s>
these goals will be more easily obtainable only if the Intergovernmental Conference , which will draw to a close within the year , results in constitutional reform , providing the Commission with real and adequate powers so that it will no longer merely implement Council decisions or Parliament 's codecisions but will have to perform the role of a real European government . </s>
the first supporter of this reform should be Parliament itself , if it really wants to increase its role of interpreting the will of the Europeans and acquire the centrality which is part of a genuinely democratic and firmly integrated Union . </s>
moreover , it will only be possible to give the Commission responsibility for the tasks it takes on according to the actual powers it will be accorded . </s>
without these prospects that we have outlined , Europe would , once again , have no future . </s>
Madam President , Mr Prodi , we are pleased about the overall intention of the objectives announced which are in line with the challenges which Europe must overcome . </s>
I note that you consider the fall of the Berlin wall to be the crucial factor of the end of the century . </s>
this event must underpin enlargement . </s>
rather than using the word ' enlargement ' , I want to talk of reunification which has much greater political significance . </s>
your idea is to concentrate your activities on the core tasks . </s>
this is one of the goals of your reform . </s>
in essence this means applying the principle of subsidiarity . </s>
precise application of this principle can only reinforce the actions taken and give our citizens a clear view of each level of competence . </s>
however , saying is one thing and doing is another ! </s>
you must therefore fight against the tendency of all institutions to try and increase their powers . </s>
I will therefore judge you on your deeds . </s>
in the meantime , I approve and encourage this clearly expressed desire in your communication . </s>
however , I must make two essential points . </s>
these concern the simplification and application of Community law . </s>
in 1998 , 123 referrals were made to the Court of Justice for non-application or non-transposition and 25 % of environmental directives were not applied or transposed . </s>
recent events have shown us that these regulations are essential . </s>
Community law must not go unapplied because it is too complex or too pedantic . </s>
the Union must not make this mistake and I therefore regret the fact that your communication does not go into more detail on this . </s>
you are being realistic when you say that the welfare state can no longer provide adequate responses to the problems facing us , including unemployment . </s>
nevertheless , I regret that a clear alternative has not been proposed . </s>
the emphasis should have been placed on the rejection of any policy of handouts and instead on the development of initiative and responsibility . </s>
you have not highlighted the ageing of our population which will fundamentally alter the structure of our society , not only economically but also in terms of public health . </s>
this is a silent revolution and in this respect I expected more from your communication . </s>
finally , you do highlight European research as being at the heart of our future . </s>
yet you do not indicate the resources you intend to implement to achieve this . </s>
also , ethical principles are at the heart of this research but your communication says nothing about these . </s>
if you want to better inform the people , you should start by strengthening liaison with this House , as we are the representatives of the citizens . </s>
Madam President , we can only endorse the general guidelines of the five-year programme and of the programme for 2000 , set out with so much enthusiasm by President Prodi this morning . </s>
in the two documents , strong emphasis is placed on the need to define new forms of European governance and , to this end , to introduce a new agenda for the Commission , establishing more stringent priorities in the pursuit of the goal of full employment , through more efficient coordination of the economic and social policies of the States , and , primarily - allow me to stress this - of the nations that have joined the monetary union and which must be enabled to become the first example of closer cooperation . </s>
to this end , I shall confine myself to stressing , out of all the choices available , the importance of three priority decisions which should , in the drawing-up of action programmes for the government of the Union , be the basis for both the Commission 's agenda and the actions of the European Union in the coming months . </s>
firstly , the promotion of and participation in the drafting of joint plans for the creation of an integrated services network in the transport and energy sectors , with the backing of the European investment Bank . </s>
secondly , the approval of investments - where the parameters are binding when drawing up action programmes on employment - to be made in individual countries via Community projects in the priority sectors of research , innovation and training . </s>
I feel that these parameters - particularly those of a qualitative nature , resulting from investments in continuous training , refresher courses , adaptability and retraining of older workers - are considerably more significant and binding owing to their lasting effects over the medium term than the simple drawing up of annual quantitative objectives , that are always debatable , regarding new employment or employment cuts . </s>
if , among other things , as the programme of the Portuguese Presidency stresses as well , the Commission could promote a new phase of social dialogue , focusing on an agreed strategy of socialisation and diffusion of knowledge , in other words , a strategy for employability and the definition of its rules , this would allow us to take a step towards having employees participate in the informed and consensual management of the restructuring and reemployment processes . </s>
thirdly , I do not think that the decrease in the number of the working population , owing to the ageing of the population , is unavoidable and inevitable for the European Union . </s>
this is not just because of the existence of margins which would permit an increase in the number of working women and immigration , but because we need to be determined in reversing the widespread trend of early retirements from the job market , and direct the coordinated reform of social welfare systems , certainly not towards large reductions in future pension payments but towards the active use of people 's increased life expectancy and towards a longer working life . </s>
Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , you have come here today , Mr Prodi , in a very reformist and ambitious mood . </s>
I welcome you and your ambition . </s>
ambition will be needed , given the mammoth task which awaits us . </s>
in order to make these reforms , however , and in order to make progress with the 2001 legislative programme , we must be very sure , not only of the strengths of the reformer himself , but also of the opinions of others . </s>
you say that you will not hesitate to come to this House to request more resources for the Commission , but the Commission must be aware that we are walking on thin financial ice . </s>
we have 1.27 % of the Community 's GDP . </s>
not a euro more or a euro less . </s>
it will not be us who refuse these new resources . </s>
you should ask the Council . </s>
these financial perspectives are adjusted to within a millimetre . </s>
in order to finance the stability plan for the Balkans , we will have to negotiate a significant revision of category 4 , and you must remember the enormous difficulties we have had in approving the 2000 budget . </s>
I would remind you that this Group , the PPE-DE , does not like to finance new political initiatives at the expense of existing ones . </s>
the political priorities must be set by this House and the MEPs . </s>
do not believe for one moment that your proposed reform of the budget will disguise the limitations of the Community financial system . </s>
it is all very well for us , by mutual consensus , to make an effort in terms of budgetary rationalisation , but you must be very aware that the lack of resources , the absence of financial autonomy and the poor execution of the budget , continue to be urgent issues which must be resolved . </s>
we therefore wonder whether the Commission has the political will to resolve them . </s>
Madam President , the Commission communication is well written but sufficiently vague to allow any interpretation whatsoever . </s>
on one hand , there are the words and , on the other , their real political meaning . </s>
we Socialists applaud the Commission for wanting to fight against social exclusion and poverty . </s>
yet how can the gulf between political rhetoric and reality be filled ? </s>
what is meant by the Commission 's declared objective of ' economic reform ' in the labour market ? </s>
does this mean more flexibility , insecurity and fixed-term contracts ? </s>
everyone knows that quality of life and full and better employment depend on sustainable economic growth . </s>
the Union is currently restricted to a policy of stability which is certainly necessary but insufficient . </s>
we Socialists desperately want a European pact for growth and employment . </s>
the ingredients of this policy are well known . </s>
they are the stimulation of public and private investment , increased investment in research , education and training and the promotion of the spirit of enterprise . </s>
in this respect , the e-Europe initiative is to be welcomed . </s>
in the world of new technologies , the main danger remains that access to information will be easier the richer you are . </s>
the gulfs which are opening up everywhere are the main problem for our era . </s>
on one hand we have the exuberance of the financial markets and the explosion of wealth and , on the other , more widespread exclusion . </s>
we are asking workers to be flexible , innovative and ever more productive , yet the fruits of this productivity increasingly benefit the shareholders alone . </s>
the European Central Bank is keeping very quiet about the staggering rates of return on financial assets , yet it never misses an opportunity to remind us that any wage increase should remain below the rate of increase in productivity . </s>
how do we explain to workers who fall victim to the rationalisations of the worldwide monopoly game that they must be prepared to change career several times in their working lives when the captains of industry , having lost the gamble of a take-over , leave with compensation of EUR 30 million ? </s>
for years we have been told over and over that the economy must be liberalised . </s>
the sectors which have been liberalised are experiencing an avalanche of mergers and acquisitions , leading inevitably to monopoly situations . </s>
all these stock market battles are based solely on forecast increases in profit of 15 % , 20 % or 25 % which are unrealistic in the long term . </s>
the unfettered rise in prices of financial assets and property means that the risks are on the increase . </s>
the main danger awaiting us in the medium term is not inflation but deflation caused by the collapse of the speculative bubbles on the international financial markets . </s>
to conclude , the next five years will be crucial . </s>
we need new rules to regulate globalisation and we need investment in the real economy and in people . </s>
we need the Member States and the Commission to ensure the social dimension of the market economy in a visible manner . </s>
Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , Commissioners , in my view , this strategy paper has two clear weaknesses . </s>
there is no point in drawing up a new economic and social agenda if you have not even finished the old one . </s>
I am thinking of transport policy and regional policy . </s>
you have excellent Commissioners for both issues in Mrs Palacio and Mr Barnier , yet still you attach too little importance to these areas . </s>
and do you know why ? </s>
just look at transport policy ; clearly it is crucial for this policy to be drawn up as a economically and ecologically sensible policy before the accession of other countries . </s>
I would be grateful if the President of the Commission would listen to what I have to say , although of course he has no obligation to do so . </s>
let me give you three examples . </s>
first : we need reasonable deregulation of the railway sector because we want to shift freight from the roads to the railways . </s>
that makes sense from an economic and an ecological point of view . </s>
without deregulation we will not make any headway with a reasonable transport policy . </s>
the same applies to European air traffic control . </s>
our citizens cannot understand that we are deregulating air traffic , but leaving 15 different sectors in the skies which are under national control , which have an adverse economic impact on the airlines and which pollute the environment . </s>
you still have not finished that agenda . </s>
Commissioner , far too little is said in your paper about regional policy . </s>
economic and social cohesion in the EU is a fundamental task of this Community . </s>
if we fail to complete it , citizens in less favoured regions will dread enlargement . </s>
we must show them that we intend to use the next five years to help them join the rich regions by promoting the less favoured regions using reasonable means . </s>
then they too will be prepared to really support enlargement and help to achieve it . </s>
Mr President of the Commission , if we do not manage to create true solidarity between the rich and the poor regions , then this Union will be all the poorer and it will not meet with the approval of the people . </s>
Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , Commissioners , the fact that we are formulating new programmes does not mean that we should neglect those older programmes which are at implementation stage . </s>
from that standpoint , it is useful that the Commission 's work programme comes back to the issues of agenda 2000 , the common agricultural policy , which includes fishing , and secondly , the activities of the structural funds . </s>
I hope this reference means that the reorganisation of the Commission currently in progress will not damage the mechanism for monitoring and implementing agenda 2000 . </s>
the agenda 2000 issues are , of course , ones that relate to your third and fourth strategic objectives , the economic and social agenda and a better quality of life . </s>
what your texts do not make apparent is the extent to which these major , high-minded objectives are compatible with the resources that the Commission intends to deploy . </s>
I do not necessarily mean financial resources . </s>
the implementation of agenda 2000 in the agricultural sector does not ultimately require more money . </s>
there must also be savings . </s>
but what we need is the analytical resources : these issues require the investment of more intellectual capital . </s>
this is because it is essential to achieve two things : the European model of multifunctionality in agriculture must be secured , and this must be done in a way which facilitates the liberalisation of world trade in agricultural products , mainly to the benefit of developing countries . </s>
it is not easy to combine those aims . </s>
there is no obvious way . </s>
there may well be contradictions between the two objectives and there is nothing to show that the Commission has pointed out those contradictions and how it proposes to deal with them . </s>
as regards the other aspect of agenda , the aspect of cohesion and regional development , there we do indeed have great achievements to point to , but there are still less developed regions , particularly island regions , to which more attention should be paid . </s>

perhaps these issues should be approached with greater attention and a greater esprit de finesse . </s>
Madam President , I want to start by reinforcing the caution that has been expressed by many colleagues here in addressing this five-year plan . </s>
in setting very ambitious long-term goals we must not take our eyes away from the present . </s>
that was a point made very forcibly by the leader of my group , Mr Poettering , in his opening address . </s>
the Union must not take on a whole range of new tasks without the basic foundation for a successful European economy being in place . </s>
that foundation is clearly the single market . </s>
how strongly is the single market established at the moment ? </s>

nearly 40 % of businesses in this survey are still reporting additional costs to render products or services compatible with national specifications . </s>
this is the Commission 's own survey . </s>
these are the classic symptoms of continued obstruction by national governments - bureaucratic red-tape blocking market entry . </s>
the Commission 's programme shows a disturbing complacency about the completion of the internal market . </s>
we have to keep the pressure up in all areas by removing further barriers , intensifying pressure on Member States who fail to implement single market measures and , of course , extending into crucial new areas like financial services . </s>

Madam President , Mr Prodi , ladies and gentlemen , at the time of our vote on your appointment we invited you to come here today . </s>
the serious business is therefore now going to start as we are to vote on your programme . </s>
from your speech I will concentrate on what you have called the new governance , which you will use as a tool for reconciliation with our fellow citizens . </s>
yet this new governance simply means how the institutions and our public authorities operate , if we agree that the European Union must be a public authority . </s>
the interlinking of the EU institutions , the responsibilities of the Member States and the local and regional authorities is all very well . </s>

is this really how we will answer the fundamental questions which are not so much about ' who does what ' but more ' what are we doing together ' ? </s>

the reason our timetable includes the drafting of this Charter is because we are at a key point in our history . </s>

Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , Commissioners , I should like to start with a quote : " the Commission will continue to work towards establishing a European Charter of fundamental rights and draw up proposals to bring about an ambitious programme . </s>

a farce because we know and appreciate the work of Commissioner Vitorino and what we have here on paper is a blatant contradiction to how things actually stand . </s>
a paper such as this is no basis for a scoreboard . </s>

we here in Parliament want to hold a serious discussion about the future development in this policy area on the basis of a programme . </s>

Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , Commissioners , I rise to speak on the subject of the world trade Organisation , on which there is a broad convergence of views between the Commission documents and the positions of the Socialist Group . </s>
this is not the case in other areas , as has already been pointed out . </s>
we share these views because we are in favour of world trade , but we want this trade to be conducted according to common standards , common rules which would regulate world trade with one aim in mind . </s>
this aim is that trade should benefit development , and particularly harmonious development in which the values of citizenship do not only apply to the world 's most dynamic and competitive regions . </s>
on the other hand , what does this statement tell us about principles ? </s>
this regulation and these standards have brought an increased volume of trade for the world trade Organisation , in other words , increased wealth , but when we look at how this wealth is distributed , we see , unfortunately , that the gulf between the world 's richest countries and blocks and the poorest and least developed countries continues to increase . </s>
it is therefore quite legitimate and even imperative that we ask ourselves , what purpose do the current common standards and rules serve ? </s>
what good are the current way in which we negotiate and the way in which the world trade Organisation works , if they cause trade to increase on the one hand , but on the other , they create problems and above all cause this gulf between rich and poor countries to grow ? </s>
that is why we said that we were in favour of the strategy that the Commission outlined here for the Seattle negotiations and for later ones . </s>
we are certainly in favour of this strategic vision but we need to be brave and ambitious . </s>
we need to be demanding and ensure that social rights , environmental rights and consumer protection are incorporated into the forthcoming negotiations . </s>
most importantly though , we must have a brave and ambitious long-term vision for reform , not just of the WTO but also of the ILO , the United Nations and above all , of the financial institutions , specifically the IMF and the world Bank . </s>
we must be brave and not only see some aspects of globalisation . </s>
we must be brave enough to have more of an overview of this process , so that wealth does not only benefit the most highly-developed blocks and countries , but that there is also harmonious change and development in every region in the world . </s>
Madam President , I would also like to welcome the Commission 's initiative of presenting us with a report on its strategic objectives for the next five years , although I hope that it intends , in subsequent documents , to avoid the excess of generalisations and the vagueness of the text which we are examining today . </s>
having said this , Madam President , I am prepared , once again , to be a voice crying in the wilderness as a result of the absence of a fishing policy . </s>
it is really surprising that the Commission does not treat the revision of one of its common policies as a strategic objective for the coming years , in view of the reform which must take place in 2002 . </s>
there is no doubt whatsoever that this revision process will be the most important thing to affect the fishing industry for many years . </s>
however , it seems that the Commission does not share this view , although it is the Commission which is obliged to present the Council and Parliament with a report on the functioning of the common fisheries policy over the last decade before the end of 2001 , and it is on this basis that the Council will have to make the appropriate decisions with regard to its modification . </s>
in fact , the revision process has already begun for many bodies and institutions , such as the European Parliament , which in 1998 already issued and adopted a report pointing out all the current problems and deficiencies of the common fisheries policy . </s>
we have often asked for a basic timetable for this revision and we have received no reply . </s>
less than two years is not much time if we bear in mind also that the fishing policy is anomalous with regard to the internal market regulations and that such anomalies should be resolved within the framework of this reform process . </s>
therefore , Madam President , Mr President of the Commission , I would ask that this issue , which is of vital importance to a very significant industry within the European Union , be taken into account in this strategy and these strategic objectives for the next five years . </s>
